subparagraph.text: After reviewing the results of the investigation described in subsection (c) of this section, the Commissioner or the Commissioner’s designee may approve, disapprove, or defer action on the placement of an inmate in the extended work-release program.
If an inmate is approved for placement in the extended work-release program, the Commissioner or the Commissioner’s designee shall adopt an extended work-release plan for the inmate.

paragraph.text: An extended work-release plan:

subparagraph.text: shall contain terms and conditions that are necessary and proper;
shall be signed by the inmate before the inmate participates in the program; and
may be conditioned on the inmate’s agreement to waive the right to contest extradition proceedings.

paragraph.text: At any time and for any reason, the Commissioner may revoke approval for an inmate to participate in the extended work-release program.

subsection.text: In addition to any other terms and conditions contained in an extended work-release plan, a plan may provide:

paragraph.text: that the inmate’s earnings be used to support the inmate’s family and reimburse the State for the inmate’s room and board; and

subparagraph.text: that the inmate work at gainful employment during necessary and reasonable hours;
that the inmate live in a controlled but noninstitutional environment, under intensive supervision by the Division of Parole and Probation; or

in special cases, to serve the general welfare and the best interests of the inmate’s family and to ensure family unity and more effective rehabilitation after expiration of sentence, that the inmate live at home under intensive supervision by the Division of Parole and Probation.

paragraph.text: An inmate who has been placed in an extended work-release plan, including an inmate who has been allowed to live at home or elsewhere, is deemed to be in the custody of the Commissioner to the same extent, and subject to the same supervision and control, as an inmate who is actually confined in a correctional facility until the inmate:

subparagraph.text: is pardoned or paroled; or
has served the inmate’s full sentence less any diminution credits awarded under Subtitle 7 of this title.

paragraph.text: If the Commissioner revokes an extended work-release plan, the inmate shall be returned to actual confinement in a correctional facility until a new plan is approved for the inmate.

subsection.text: Other State units, including the Department of Human Resources and the Division of Parole and Probation, shall cooperate with the Division to implement and accomplish the objectives of the extended work-release program.
The Commissioner may adopt regulations to implement the extended work-release program.

paragraph.text: An inmate who is released from actual confinement under an extended work-release program may not willfully violate the terms of authorization for release in the inmate’s extended work-release plan.
An inmate who knowingly violates paragraph (1) of this subsection is guilty of escape and on conviction is subject to the penalties of § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: The Commissioner, the Deputy Commissioner, the Assistant Commissioner for Operations, or the Assistant Commissioner for Administration may grant compassionate leave to an inmate confined in a correctional facility in the Division to visit a member of the inmate’s immediate family who is seriously ill or attend the funeral of a member of the inmate’s immediate family.

paragraph.text: When granting compassionate leave to an inmate, the Commissioner, the Deputy Commissioner, the Assistant Commissioner for Operations, or the Assistant Commissioner for Administration shall:

subparagraph.text: issue a written authorization that:

sub-subparagraph.text: specifies the conditions of the compassionate leave; and
may be conditioned on the inmate’s agreement to waive the right to contest extradition proceedings; and

subparagraph.text: file a copy of the authorization in the Commissioner’s office.

paragraph.text: While on compassionate leave, an inmate at all times shall possess a copy of the authorization for compassionate leave.
The duration of compassionate leave shall include reasonable time:

subparagraph.text: for travel; and
for fulfilling the purpose of the leave.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may require an inmate to whom compassionate leave is granted or anyone acting on the inmate’s behalf to reimburse the Division for the expenses incurred by the Division in granting the leave.

subsection.text: The failure of an inmate to comply with the terms of the inmate’s authorization for compassionate leave is a violation of § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.
The Commissioner may adopt regulations to carry out this section.

The Commissioner, the Deputy Commissioner, the Assistant Commissioner for Operations, or the Assistant Commissioner for Administration may grant special leave within or outside of the State as provided under this section to an inmate who:

paragraph.text: is confined in a correctional facility in the Division;
has been selected to participate in a prerelease program; and
is within 3 months of the inmate’s anticipated release.

subsection.text: The Commissioner, the Deputy Commissioner, the Assistant Commissioner for Operations, or the Assistant Commissioner for Administration may grant special leave to an inmate:

paragraph.text: for an employment interview;
as part of a prerelease program relating to employment; or
to participate in a community treatment or educational program that will contribute to the inmate’s rehabilitation.
The Commissioner, the Deputy Commissioner, the Assistant Commissioner for Operations, or the Assistant Commissioner for Administration:

subparagraph.text: may grant weekend leave to an inmate if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the inmate has participated for at least 2 months in a prerelease program as authorized under this section; and
the inmate’s direct Division supervisor in the prerelease program recommends the inmate for weekend leave; and

subparagraph.text: shall establish the terms and conditions of weekend leave, which may include the inmate’s agreement to waive the right to contest extradition proceedings.

paragraph.text: Weekend leave may not begin before 6 p.m. on Friday or end after 6 p.m. on the Sunday that immediately follows.

subsection.text: On the recommendation of treatment staff and with the approval of the managing official of a correctional facility in the Division, the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner may grant special leave to an inmate to allow an inmate to participate in a special community or other meritorious program or activity within or outside of the State that the Commissioner and managing official believe:

paragraph.text: would benefit the inmate;
would not be detrimental to the public; and
would help rehabilitate the inmate.

subsection.text: The Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner may grant special leave for the purpose of allowing an inmate to:

paragraph.text: attend an educational program;
improve job skills;
attend a trade licensing examination;
be interviewed for employment;
participate as a volunteer for a governmental unit in an activity that serves the general public;
participate in athletic competition;
participate in a civic activity that benefits the inmate or the community; or
participate in a residential or nonresidential treatment program including a program for pregnant women or a program to establish bonding between mothers and newborn children.

subsection.text: An inmate granted leave under this section may be allowed to remain outside the institution for any period of time consistent with public safety.

paragraph.text: An inmate is not eligible for special leave under this section unless the managing official and Commissioner concur that positive attitudinal and growth patterns are being established.
Special leave shall be issued in writing and signed personally by both the managing official and either the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner.
As a condition of granting special leave, the Commissioner may require that the inmate agree to waive the right to contest extradition proceedings.
The Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner shall file the order granting special leave in the Division.

subsection.text: The Commissioner or Commissioner’s designee may grant family leave to allow an inmate to visit the inmate’s family for a reasonable time if the inmate:

paragraph.text: is confined in a correctional facility in the Division;
is classified to be in prerelease status; and
is recommended by the correctional facility’s case management team and managing official.
When granting family leave to an inmate, the Commissioner or Commissioner’s designee shall:

subparagraph.text: issue a written authorization to the inmate that specifies the conditions of the family leave; and
file a copy of the authorization in the Commissioner’s office.

paragraph.text: While on family leave, an inmate at all times shall possess a copy of the authorization for family leave.

subsection.text: The failure of an inmate to comply with the terms of the authorization for family leave is a violation of § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.
The Commissioner may adopt regulations to carry out this section.

Whenever an individual is sentenced to death, the judge of the court where the conviction takes place shall cause the individual to be taken into custody by the sheriff of the county in which the individual was indicted.

paragraph.text: While the inmate is in the custody of the sheriff, the sheriff shall:

subparagraph.text: hold the inmate under guard as the sheriff determines to be necessary; and
keep the inmate in solitary confinement in the same manner as is required when the inmate is in the custody of the Division.

paragraph.text: As soon as possible, the sheriff shall deliver the inmate to the Division to await the execution of the inmate’s sentence.

subsection.text: The expenses of the Division relating to the detention of an inmate under sentence of death, including the expenses of guarding, lodging, feeding, clothing, and caring for the inmate, may not be assessed against, billed to, or paid by the county in which the inmate was indicted.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “State postconviction review process” means the initial adjudication of a postconviction petition filed under § 7-103 of the Criminal Procedure Article, including any appellate review of the postconviction proceeding.
“State postconviction review process” does not include:

sub-subparagraph.text: a postconviction proceeding that has been reopened under § 7-104 of the Criminal Procedure Article or any appellate review of the proceeding; or
a postconviction proceeding on a second petition filed before October 1, 1995, or any appellate review of the proceeding.

paragraph.text: “Warrant of execution” means a warrant for the execution of a sentence of death on the individual against whom the sentence was imposed.
A warrant of execution shall:

subparagraph.text: state the conviction and sentence;
designate a 5-day period, beginning on a Monday, within which the sentence must be executed; and
command the Commissioner to carry out the death penalty on a day within the designated period.

paragraph.text: The period designated in a warrant of execution shall begin not less than 4 weeks and not more than 8 weeks after the warrant of execution is issued.

subsection.text: At the time an individual is sentenced to death, the judge presiding in the court shall issue a warrant of execution directed to the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: A warrant of execution is stayed during the direct review process and the State postconviction review process.

If the original warrant of execution has not expired at the end of the State postconviction review process, the judge who imposed the sentence of death or the judge then presiding in the court in which the sentence was imposed shall lift the stay imposed under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

If the original warrant of execution has expired at the end of the State postconviction review process, the judge who imposed the sentence of death or the judge then presiding in the court in which the sentence was imposed shall issue another warrant of execution.
If the Governor is satisfied that a medical examination shows that an inmate is pregnant, the Governor shall revoke a warrant of execution for the inmate.
As soon as the Governor is satisfied that the inmate is no longer pregnant, the Governor promptly shall issue another warrant of execution.
The Governor may grant a stay of a warrant of execution for any cause.
If the Governor grants a stay under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: the Governor shall issue an order revoking the warrant of execution; and
the sentence of death may not be executed until the Governor issues another warrant of execution.

paragraph.text: The Governor promptly shall notify the Commissioner of an order that revokes a warrant of execution.
The Commissioner shall set a time, within the period designated in the warrant of execution, when the sentence of death shall be executed.
No previous announcement of the day or time of the execution may be made except to those who are invited or allowed to be present as provided in this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this section, “official” means:

paragraph.text: the Commissioner; or
the sheriff of the county in which an inmate was indicted.

If the Governor grants a reprieve to an inmate under sentence of death or a court imposes a stay on the execution of a sentence of death, the Governor or court shall serve notice of the reprieve or stay on:

subparagraph.text: the inmate; and
the official who has custody of the inmate.

paragraph.text: The official who has custody of the inmate shall obey the reprieve or stay.

subsection.text: An inmate who is granted a reprieve or stay shall remain in the custody of the official who receives notice under subsection (b)(1)(ii) of this section.

paragraph.text: In any subsequent judicial proceeding, the court shall serve any court order regarding an inmate on:

subparagraph.text: the inmate; and
the official who has custody of the inmate.

paragraph.text: If a court resentences an inmate to death, the provisions of this subtitle shall apply to the new sentence in the same manner as the original sentence.

subparagraph.text: If a new trial is granted to an inmate who is in the custody of the Commissioner, the inmate shall be transported back to the place of trial under guard as the Commissioner directs.
The expenses relating to the transportation of an inmate back to the place of trial under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph shall be paid by the Division.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Incompetent” means the state of mind of an inmate who, as a result of a mental disorder or mental retardation, lacks awareness:

subparagraph.text: of the fact of the inmate’s impending execution; and
that the inmate is to be executed for the crime of murder.

paragraph.text: “Inmate” means an individual who has been convicted of murder and sentenced to death.

subsection.text: An inmate is not incompetent under this section merely because the inmate’s competence depends on continuing treatment, including the use of medication.
The State may not execute a sentence of death against an inmate who has become incompetent.

paragraph.text: A petition that alleges that an inmate is incompetent and that seeks to revoke a warrant of execution against the inmate may be filed by:

subparagraph.text: the inmate;
if the inmate is represented by counsel, counsel for the inmate; or
if the inmate is not represented by counsel, any other person on the inmate’s behalf.

paragraph.text: The petition shall be filed in the circuit court of the county in which the inmate is confined.
On the filing of the petition, the court may stay any warrant of execution that was previously issued and has not yet expired.
The petition must be accompanied by an affidavit of at least one psychiatrist that:

subparagraph.text: is based, at least in part, on personal examination;
states that in the psychiatrist’s medical opinion the inmate is incompetent; and
states the pertinent facts on which the opinion is based.

paragraph.text: A copy of the petition shall be served on the Attorney General and the Office of the State’s Attorney that prosecuted the inmate, in accordance with the service requirements of the Maryland Rules.

Unless the inmate is already represented by counsel, the court promptly shall appoint the public defender or, if the public defender for good cause declines representation, other counsel to represent the inmate in the proceeding.

Unless the State’s Attorney stipulates to the inmate’s incompetence, the State’s Attorney shall cause the inmate to be examined and evaluated by one or more psychiatrists selected by the State’s Attorney.
If the inmate’s request is reasonable and timely made, an inmate is entitled to be independently examined by a psychiatrist that the inmate selects.
Unless, with the court’s approval, the parties waive a hearing, the administrative judge of the court shall designate a time for an evidentiary hearing to determine the inmate’s competence.
A hearing under this section shall be held without a jury:

subparagraph.text: in court;
at the place where the inmate is confined; or
at another convenient place.

paragraph.text: At the hearing, the inmate:

subparagraph.text: subject to reasonable restrictions related to the inmate’s condition, may be present;
through counsel, may offer evidence, cross–examine witnesses against the inmate, and make argument; and
has the burden of establishing incompetence by a preponderance of the evidence.

subsection.text: The court shall enter an order that:

paragraph.text: declares the inmate to be competent or incompetent; and
states the findings on which the declaration is based.

subsection.text: If the court finds the inmate to be competent, the court immediately:

paragraph.text: shall lift any stay of a warrant of execution that was previously issued and has not yet expired; or
if all previously issued warrants of execution have expired, shall notify the court that imposed the sentence of death and request that the court issue a new warrant of execution.
If the court finds the inmate to be incompetent, the court shall:

subparagraph.text: stay any warrant of execution that was previously issued and has not yet expired; and
remand the case to the court in which the sentence of death was imposed.

paragraph.text: The court in which the sentence of death was imposed shall strike the sentence of death and enter in its place a sentence of life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.
The sentence of life imprisonment without the possibility of parole imposed under paragraph (2) of this subsection is mandatory and may not be suspended wholly or partly.
There is no right of appeal from an order issued by a circuit court under this section.
Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, either party may seek review in the Court of Appeals by filing an application for leave to appeal in accordance with the Maryland Rules.
If an application for leave to appeal is filed, the Court of Appeals may stay any warrant of execution that was previously issued and has not yet expired.
Not earlier than 6 months after a finding of competence, the inmate may petition the court for a redetermination of competence.
The petition must be accompanied by an affidavit of at least one psychiatrist that:

subparagraph.text: is based, at least in part, on personal examination;
states that in the psychiatrist’s medical opinion the inmate is incompetent;
states that the incompetence arose since the previous finding of competence; and
states the pertinent facts on which each opinion is based, including the facts that show the change in the inmate’s condition since the previous finding.

paragraph.text: Proceedings on a petition under this subsection shall be in accordance with subsections (d) through (i) of this section.

subsection.text: The Maryland Rules shall govern:

paragraph.text: the form of petitions and all other pleadings; and

except as otherwise provided in this section, the procedures to be followed by the circuit court in determining competency or incompetency and by the Court of Appeals in reviewing applications for leave to appeal.

subsection.text: This section does not affect the power of the Governor to stay execution of a sentence of death under § 3–902(f) of this subtitle or to commute a sentence of death under § 7–601 of this article.

The manner of inflicting the punishment of death shall be the continuous intravenous administration of a lethal quantity of an ultrashort-acting barbiturate or other similar drug in combination with a chemical paralytic agent until a licensed physician pronounces death according to accepted standards of medical practice.

paragraph.text: The administration of the lethal substances required by this section is not the practice of medicine.
Notwithstanding any other law, a pharmacist or pharmaceutical supplier may dispense drugs, without a prescription, to the Commissioner or the Commissioner’s designee to carry out this section.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall:

paragraph.text: provide a suitable and efficient place, enclosed from public view, in which an execution may be carried out;
provide all of the materials that are necessary to perform the execution; and
subject to subsection (c) of this section, select the individuals to perform the execution.

subsection.text: The Commissioner or the Commissioner’s designee shall supervise the execution.

paragraph.text: An execution shall be performed by individuals who are selected by the Commissioner and trained to administer the lethal injection.
An individual who administers the paralytic agent and lethal injection need not be licensed or certified as any type of health care practitioner under the Health Occupations Article.

subsection.text: In addition to those individuals who are otherwise required to supervise, perform, or participate in an execution, the Commissioner shall select at least 6 but not more than 12 respectable citizens to observe the execution.
Counsel for the inmate and a member of the clergy may be present at the execution.

section.text: The Commissioner shall:

paragraph.text: prepare and sign a certificate that states:

subparagraph.text: the time and place of execution; and
that the execution was conducted in accordance with the sentence of the court and the provisions of this subtitle;

paragraph.text: request that each witness of the execution sign the certificate; and
file the certificate within 10 days after the execution with the clerk of the court in the county in which the inmate was indicted.

subsection.text: On application of a relative, the body of an executed inmate shall be returned to the relative at the relative’s cost.
If an application is not made under subsection (a) of this section, the Commissioner shall arrange for burial.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board of Review” means the institutional Board of Review created under § 4-205 of this title.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Correction.
“Director” means the Director of the Patuxent Institution.

paragraph.text: “Eligible person” means an individual who:

subparagraph.text: has been convicted of a crime and is serving a sentence of imprisonment with at least 3 years remaining on the sentence;
has an intellectual impairment or emotional imbalance;
is likely to respond favorably to the programs and services that the Institution provides;
can better respond to remediation through those programs and services than by other incarceration; and
meets the eligibility criteria that the Secretary establishes under § 4-208(b) of this title.

paragraph.text: “Eligible person” does not include an individual who:

subparagraph.text: is serving two or more sentences of imprisonment for life under § 2-201, § 2-303, or § 2-304 of the Criminal Law Article;

is serving one or more sentences of imprisonment for life when a court or jury has found under § 2-303 of the Criminal Law Article, beyond a reasonable doubt, that one or more aggravating circumstances existed; or

has been convicted of murder in the first degree, rape in the first degree, or a sexual offense in the first degree, unless the sentencing judge, at the time of sentencing or in the exercise of the judge’s revisory power under the Maryland Rules, recommends that the individual be referred to the Institution for evaluation.

subsection.text: “Evaluation team” means a team of at least three professional employees of the Institution, one of whom shall be a social worker, one of whom shall be a psychologist, and one of whom shall be a psychiatrist.
“Institution” means the Patuxent Institution.
“Patuxent programs” includes the eligible person program as defined in § 4-301 of this title, and the Patuxent Youth Program as defined in § 4-401 of this title.
“Remediation” means treatment for specific areas of mental and social deficiencies that are highly related to criminal behavior.
“Victim” means:

paragraph.text: an individual who suffers personal physical injury or death as a direct result of a crime; or
if the victim is deceased, a designated family member of the victim.

section.text: There is a Patuxent Institution in the Department.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Institution is to provide remediation programs and services to youthful offenders, other eligible persons, and mentally ill inmates including a range of program alternatives indicated by the current state of knowledge to be appropriate and effective for the population being served.
The Institution shall establish and maintain, as an integral part of the programs, an effective research, development, and training effort to evaluate and recommend improvements on an ongoing basis.

paragraph.text: No more than 350 eligible persons may be enrolled in the eligible person remediation program.
The Institution may provide other remediation programs that the Secretary designates.

subsection.text: The Director is the chief administrative officer of the Institution.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall appoint the Director.
The Director shall be a trained and competent administrator.
The Director serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
The Director is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: Subject to the authority of the Secretary, the Director shall manage and supervise the Institution and implement its programs and services.

paragraph.text: On or before October 31 of each year, the Director shall submit an annual report to the Secretary and the Governor.
The annual report shall state:

subparagraph.text: the Institution’s expenses, receipts, disbursements, condition, and progress;
the number of inmates and each inmate’s age, sex, race, place of birth and conviction, crime, and term of confinement;
the number of inmates who are admitted to each of the Patuxent programs;
the number of Division of Correction inmates receiving care during the year at Patuxent Institution for mental health conditions;
the number of Patuxent program inmates who are pardoned, or discharged;
the number of inmates evaluated at the Institution for each of the Patuxent programs;
the decisions of the Board of Review to grant leave to Patuxent program inmates;
the number of rearrests, reconvictions, reincarcerations, and parole violations of individuals released from incarceration through a Patuxent program;
the number of eligible persons who are removed from each Patuxent program and returned to the Division of Correction;
a summary of the reasons underlying an individual’s transfer to the Division of Correction as described in item (ix) of this paragraph;
information on educational programs and community reentry activities; and
any remarks and suggestions the Director considers necessary to advance the interests of the Institution.

paragraph.text: The Director shall verify the report required by this subsection.

Subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the Governor shall submit to the General Assembly the report required under this subsection and any recommendation that the Governor considers expedient.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations regarding the annual report required under this subsection.

subsection.text: The Institution shall have the following staff:

paragraph.text: two associate directors, one of whom is a competent psychiatrist with at least 3 years of experience in the practice or teaching of psychiatry and one of whom is a competent behavioral scientist with at least 3 years of experience in the practice or teaching of the individual’s specialty in behavioral science;
a warden;
at least three additional psychiatrists or clinical psychologists;
at least four State licensed certified social workers–clinical; and
other professional and nonprofessional staff, as provided in the State budget.
The associate directors shall assist primarily in discharging the diagnostic and remediation functions of the Institution.
The warden shall assist primarily in discharging the custodial function of the Institution.

subsection.text: The staff members of the Institution are entitled to compensation as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection or any other law, the staff members of the Institution are in the skilled service or professional service in the State Personnel Management System.
With the approval of the Secretary, the Director shall appoint an individual to any position that the Secretary determines to be professional, including:

subparagraph.text: each associate director;
each social worker;
each sociologist;
each physician; and
each psychologist.

paragraph.text: The Director and each individual appointed under paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection are in the executive service, in the management service, or a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: There is a Board of Review for the Institution.
The Board of Review consists of the following nine members:

paragraph.text: the Director;
the two associate directors;
the warden; and
five members of the public, one of whom is a member of a victim’s rights organization, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

subsection.text: The Governor shall designate the chairperson of the Board of Review.

paragraph.text: Seven members of the Board of Review, including at least three public members, constitute a quorum.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, each action of the Board of Review requires the approval of 5 members.
A decision to grant parole, work release, or leave to an eligible person requires the approval of seven members of the Board of Review.

paragraph.text: Employees of the Institution who are members of the Board of Review or who attend meetings of or work as advisors to the Board of Review shall serve in that capacity as part of their regular duties without additional compensation.
The members of the Board of Review appointed from the public are entitled to compensation as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The term of a member of the Board of Review appointed from the public is 4 years.
The Board of Review shall perform the duties set forth in this title.
A member of the Board of Review, the Director, or an employee of the Institution may not:

paragraph.text: be interested, directly or indirectly, in any contract, purchase, or sale made by or for the Institution or an inmate of the Institution;
accept a reward or gift or a promise of a reward or gift from a person interested in a contract, purchase, or sale made by or for the Institution or an inmate of the Institution; or
accept a reward, gift, devise, or bequest or a promise of a reward, gift, devise, or bequest from an inmate of the Institution or from anyone on the inmate’s behalf.
A reward, gift, devise, bequest, or promise accepted in violation of this section is void.
A contract, purchase, or sale in which a person has an interest prohibited by subsection (a) of this section is voidable by the State whether or not the State is a party to it.

subsection.text: A member of the Board of Review, the Director, or an employee of the Institution shall report to the Director or the Secretary any violation of subsection (a) of this section that is within the individual’s knowledge.

paragraph.text: An individual who violates this section is guilty of misconduct in office.
A violation of this section is grounds for removal from office or employment.

subsection.text: There is a Citizens Advisory Board.
Based on recommendations of the Secretary, the Governor shall appoint the members of the Citizens Advisory Board.
The Citizens Advisory Board shall advise the Director and the Secretary with respect to the operation and programs of the Institution.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out this title.

Notwithstanding § 10-101(g)(2)(i) of the State Government Article, the regulations adopted under this section, other than regulations pertaining only to routine internal management of the Institution, shall comply with the Administrative Procedure Act, including regulations that:

paragraph.text: govern criteria to determine eligibility for referral of an inmate to the Institution;
govern leave, work release, and parole from the Institution; and
establish with specificity what constitutes a major violation of the Institution’s disciplinary rules.

subsection.text: The Institution shall compile and maintain a complete record of each inmate transferred to it for evaluation or treatment.
The record shall include the following materials to the extent that the materials are physically available and the inclusion is not prohibited by federal law:

paragraph.text: police reports and other relevant information concerning the crime of which the inmate was most recently convicted and the sentence imposed for that conviction;
the inmate’s criminal and juvenile history and all relevant records concerning this history;
presentence investigation, parole, probation, and other reports concerning the inmate;
school records;
information concerning the inmate’s medical and mental health history, including relevant medical and hospital records and reports; and
all other relevant information, records, and reports concerning the inmate’s social, physical, or mental condition and history.
The Institution shall record a full and accurate description, including photographs, of each inmate transferred to the Institution for treatment.
The Institution may adopt the Bertillon method or any other accurate method of description, measurement, and registration.
In order that the Institution may comply with this section, all State and local officials and units:

subparagraph.text: shall cooperate with the Institution; and
promptly, on request of the Institution, shall furnish or cause to be furnished to the Institution the information, records, and reports in their possession.

paragraph.text: The provisions of § 3-8A-27(b) of the Courts Article do not apply to a request made for juvenile records under this section.

subsection.text: To the extent that any record, report, or information compiled under this section is legally confidential, it shall remain confidential and may not be disclosed to any person or unit except to:

paragraph.text: the Commissioner or the Commissioner’s authorized staff;
the Division of Parole and Probation;
the Maryland Parole Commission;
a State’s Attorney, when required in the prosecution or defense of a proceeding in court;

a federal, State, or local law enforcement officer on a written request signed by an authorized commanding officer of the law enforcement unit certifying that the record, report, or information is needed for a pending investigation;
an authorized correctional official or probation officer of:

subparagraph.text: the United States; or
a state, if that jurisdiction has made reciprocal provision by law to furnish similar records, reports, or information to comparable officials of this State;

paragraph.text: the Attorney General;
the Inmate Grievance Office, to the extent relevant to a matter pending before it and with the written consent of the inmate to whom the record, report, or information pertains;
the Division of Rehabilitation Services of the Department of Education solely to determine if an inmate confined at the Institution qualifies for benefits provided by that Division;
providers of medical care to the extent necessary to ensure proper medical treatment;
a judge of a circuit court or the District Court when required in connection with a pretrial release, presentence, or postsentence investigation; and

State, local, and federal units and private agencies to the extent that the release of the record, report, or information will benefit an eligible person but only with the written consent of the inmate to whom the record, report, or information pertains.

subsection.text: Confidential records, reports, or information may be disclosed under subsection (e) of this section only if the Director reasonably believes that the record, report, or information:

paragraph.text: will be used solely for the legitimate purposes of the person or unit receiving it; and
will not be further disseminated to any person or unit not authorized to receive it under subsection (e) of this section.

subsection.text: Juvenile records obtained under subsection (d) of this section may be disclosed only:

paragraph.text: to a person or unit listed in subsection (e)(1), (2), and (3) of this section; and
in accordance with subsection (f) of this section.

subsection.text: On the recommendation of a health care provider, the Director or Director’s designee may authorize medical treatment of a juvenile inmate when:

paragraph.text: in the judgment of the Director or designee, the treatment is necessary; and
a parent, guardian, or person in loco parentis of the juvenile is not available on a timely basis to give the authorization.

subsection.text: The Director or Director’s designee may not be held liable for authorizing in good faith medically necessary treatment under subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: The Director may determine whether, to what extent, and which inmates of the Institution shall supply produce and other goods required to be purchased by contracting units or political subdivisions under Title 3, Subtitle 5 of this article.

Subject to any approval required by law, the Director may apply for and receive from any unit of government or private person a grant or loan of funds or goods to be used in the maintenance or programs of the Institution.

subsection.text: An inmate confined at the Institution shall be released under mandatory supervision, as defined in § 7-101 of this article, in the same manner and subject to the same conditions as if the inmate were being released from a correctional facility in the Division of Correction.
The Director may establish special programs or projects for diminution credit award to the same extent that such credits may be awarded in the Division of Correction.

The Director may restore to inmates at Patuxent Institution any diminution credits rescinded upon adjudication of violation of institutional disciplinary rules to the same extent as such credits may be restored by the Commissioner of Correction to inmates in the Division.
The Director may impose special terms and conditions on any inmate released on mandatory supervision from the Institution.

If the Secretary reassigns supervisory responsibility of a mandatory releasee from the Division of Parole and Probation to the Institution in accordance with § 2-117 of this article, the Secretary may also reassign the authority to revoke mandatory supervision release to the Board of Review.

paragraph.text: The Director may request that the Commissioner refer an inmate to the Institution for evaluation as to whether the inmate is an eligible person if the inmate:

subparagraph.text: is serving a sentence of imprisonment following conviction of a crime;
has more than 3 years remaining to serve on a sentence;
has not been evaluated by or confined at the Institution within the preceding 3 years;
is not disqualified from being an eligible person under § 4-101(e)(2) of this title; and
meets the eligibility criteria that the Secretary establishes under § 4-208(b) of this title.

paragraph.text: The request that the Commissioner refer an inmate to the Institution shall be based:

subparagraph.text: on recommendation of the sentencing court;
on application by the inmate or the State’s Attorney of the county in which the inmate was last convicted; or
on the Commissioner’s own initiative.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall promptly refer any inmate requested for evaluation by the Director unless the Commissioner determines that such a referral will constitute a security risk.
Within 6 months after an inmate is referred to the Institution, an evaluation team shall examine the inmate.
Before proceeding with the examination, the evaluation team shall assemble and review all available and relevant information about the inmate provided for in § 4-209 of this title.

Based on the information reviewed under subsection (b)(2) of this section and an examination of the inmate, the evaluation team shall determine whether, in the opinion of a majority of the team, the inmate is an eligible person.
The evaluation team shall submit to the Director a written report that states its findings.
The report shall state in detail the reasoning supporting the team’s conclusion with respect to each of the criteria for an eligible person set forth in § 4-101(e) of this title.

If the evaluation team determines under § 4-301(c) of this subtitle that an inmate is not an eligible person, the Director shall notify the Commissioner and send to the Commissioner a copy of the evaluation team’s report.
Within 30 days after sending the notice, the inmate shall be delivered to the appropriate correctional facility that the Commissioner designates.

subsection.text: If the evaluation team determines under § 4-301(c) of this subtitle that the inmate is an eligible person, the Director shall notify the Commissioner and the inmate shall be admitted to the eligible person remediation program if the admission does not exceed the program capacity specified in § 4-202(c) of this title.

paragraph.text: The evaluation team shall prepare, file with the Director, and implement an individualized written remediation plan for each eligible person.
The Director or an associate director for treatment shall review the remediation plan and the eligible person’s progress under it at appropriate intervals not exceeding every 6 months.
At least once a year, following a new evaluation by an evaluation team, the Board of Review shall review an inmate’s status as an eligible person and the inmate’s progress under the remediation plan.
After its review, the Board of Review shall make appropriate written recommendations for the future remediation and status of the eligible person.
The Institution shall maintain a copy of these recommendations as part of the inmate’s file.

subsection.text: An inmate transferred to the Institution for evaluation or treatment remains in the custody of the Division of Correction and under the sentence imposed on the inmate, but the inmate is subject to the immediate control of the Institution and its staff.

paragraph.text: Subject to § 4–305 of this subtitle, inmates transferred to the Institution for treatment are eligible for the work release and leave of absence programs provided for in §§ 3–801 through 3–806 and 3–808 through 3–811 of this article.

The Board of Review shall perform the functions of the warden and the Commissioner under §§ 3–801 through 3–806 and 3–808 through 3–811 of this article with respect to inmates confined in the Institution.

The Board of Review may not grant an eligible person work release or leave under this section until the Board of Review mails written notice to the victim that the Board of Review intends to decide whether to grant work release or leave to the eligible person.

Before the Board of Review decides whether to grant work release or leave to an eligible person, the Board of Review shall give the victim a reasonable opportunity to comment in writing on work release or leave or to present oral testimony in the manner that the Board of Review establishes by regulation.
The Board of Review promptly shall notify the victim of the decision of the Board of Review regarding work release or leave.
The victim may designate, in writing to the Board of Review, the name and address of a representative who is a resident of the State to receive notice for the victim.

The Board of Review shall delete the victim’s address and phone number from a document before the Board of Review allows examination of the document by the eligible person or the eligible person’s representative.

section.text: Unless previously released on parole or mandatory supervision, an inmate confined at the Institution shall be released on expiration of sentence.

subsection.text: After transfer of an inmate to the Institution for treatment as an eligible person but before expiration of the inmate’s sentence, the Board of Review may grant a parole from the Institution for a period not exceeding 1 year if the Board of Review concludes that the parole:

paragraph.text: will not impose an unreasonable risk on society; and
will assist in the remediation of the eligible person.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an inmate sentenced to life imprisonment is not eligible for parole consideration until the inmate has served 15 years or the equivalent of 15 years when considering allowances for diminution of the inmate’s period of confinement as provided under Title 3, Subtitle 7 of this article and § 6–218 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

An inmate sentenced to life imprisonment as a result of a proceeding under § 2–303 or § 2–304 of the Criminal Law Article is not eligible for parole consideration until the inmate has served 25 years or the equivalent of 25 years when considering allowances for diminution of the inmate’s period of confinement as provided under Title 3, Subtitle 7 of this article and § 6–218 of the Criminal Procedure Article.
Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, an eligible person who is serving a term of life imprisonment may be paroled only with the Governor’s approval.

subparagraph.text: If the Board of Review decides to grant parole to an eligible person sentenced to life imprisonment who has served 25 years without application of diminution of confinement credits, and the Secretary approves the decision, the decision shall be transmitted to the Governor.
The Governor may disapprove the decision by written transmittal to the Board of Review.
If the Governor does not disapprove the decision within 180 days after receipt, the decision becomes effective.

paragraph.text: The Board of Review may:

subparagraph.text: attach reasonable conditions to parole granted under this section;
make reasonable and appropriate modifications of the conditions at any time; and
revoke the parole if the Board of Review finds that the individual has violated a condition of the parole.

paragraph.text: The Board of Review:

subparagraph.text: shall review an individual’s status before the expiration of the parole period; and
may extend the parole.

paragraph.text: The Board of Review shall mail to the victim written notice of an eligible person’s parole hearing.

Before the Board decides whether to grant parole to an eligible person, the Board of Review shall give the victim a reasonable opportunity to comment on the parole in writing or to present oral testimony in the manner that the Board of Review establishes by regulation.
The Board of Review promptly shall notify the victim of the decision of the Board of Review regarding parole.
The victim may designate, in writing to the Board of Review, the name and address of a representative who is a resident of the State to receive notice for the victim.

The Board of Review shall delete the victim’s address and phone number from a document before the Board of Review allows examination of the document by the eligible person or the eligible person’s representative.

subsection.text: The Board of Review may not release an eligible person on parole until the Secretary approves the parole decision.

paragraph.text: If an individual has completed successfully 3 years on parole without violation and the Board of Review concludes that the individual is safe to be permanently released, the Board of Review, through the Director, may petition the court that last sentenced the individual to:

subparagraph.text: suspend the individual’s remaining sentence and terminate parole supervision on the conditions the court considers appropriate; or
vacate the individual’s remaining sentence.
The Director shall serve notice of the petition on the victim and the State’s Attorney who last prosecuted the individual.
The State’s Attorney shall be a party to the proceeding.

paragraph.text: After a hearing, the court may either grant or deny the relief requested in the petition.

subsection.text: After transfer of an inmate to the Institution for treatment as an eligible person but before the inmate’s sentence expires, on review of the inmate, the Board of Review may take any of the actions specified in subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: If an inmate submits a written request for a transfer to the Division of Correction, the Director shall notify the Commissioner and send the Commissioner a copy of any evaluation team’s report that has been completed.

If the Board of Review concludes that an inmate is no longer an eligible person but should remain confined in the Division of Correction subject to the authority of the Maryland Parole Commission until release on expiration of sentence or mandatory supervision, the Director shall notify the Commissioner and send the Commissioner a copy of the evaluation team’s report.
Within 90 days after notice is provided under paragraph (1) or (2) of this subsection, the inmate shall be delivered to the appropriate correctional facility that the Commissioner designates.
A transfer under this subsection does not affect any right to parole consideration that the inmate may have at the time of transfer.
In this subsection, “major violation” includes:

subparagraph.text: escape from parole, work release, or leave;
failure to return from parole, work release, or leave within 1 hour of the time due, unless the failure to return was due to causes beyond the control of the eligible person;
commission of a new crime, other than a minor traffic violation, while on parole, work release, or leave;
commission of a Category I violation of the Department’s disciplinary rules; and
use of a controlled dangerous substance that the eligible person is not entitled to use under the laws of the State.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, if an inmate in the Eligible Person Program or the Patuxent Youth Program commits a major violation while on parole, work release, or leave, the Board of Review may impose appropriate sanctions consistent with the best interests of public safety.

If the Board of Review or the Secretary determines that a major violation was severe enough to warrant removing an eligible person from the Institution, the eligible person may be removed from the Institution and returned to the Division of Correction to serve the remainder of the eligible person’s original sentence.

If an eligible person commits a second major violation while on parole, work release, or leave, the eligible person shall be removed from the Institution and returned to the Division of Correction to serve the remainder of the eligible person’s original sentence.

section.text: If a court has ordered that an eligible person make restitution as part of a sentence or as a condition of probation, the Board of Review shall require the eligible person to make restitution payments while on parole or work release as a condition of parole or work release.

An inmate who is transferred to the Institution for evaluation or treatment shall receive full credit against a sentence for the time spent at the Institution, including allowances or disallowances for diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement under Title 3, Subtitle 7 of this article as the Director determines.

subsection.text: In this section, “Youth Program” means the Patuxent Institution Youth Program.
There is a Patuxent Institution Youth Program.
This section applies to an individual under the age of 21 years who is sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 3 years or more.
At sentencing, a court may refer an individual to the Institution for evaluation.
The Director shall:

paragraph.text: review recommendations of a court for admission of an individual to the Youth Program; and
admit or deny admission of an individual based on the criteria for admission established under subsection (j) of this section.

subsection.text: An inmate’s status in the Youth Program shall be reviewed by the Board of Review on an annual basis.

The Board of Review may grant an inmate in the Youth Program leave, work or school release, or parole according to the same procedures and with the same notice to victims as required with respect to the eligible person program.
If an individual is transferred to the Youth Program under this section, the duration of the transfer to the Institution shall terminate when:

paragraph.text: the Director orders the individual transferred to the Division of Correction;
the Board of Review orders the individual transferred to the Division of Correction;
with the approval of the Secretary, the Board of Review orders the individual paroled; or
the individual completes the individual’s term of confinement as provided by law.

subsection.text: An individual who is transferred to the Youth Program as provided under this section is deemed to be committed to the custody of and subject to the jurisdiction of the Institution.

paragraph.text: Regulations adopted by the Secretary under § 4-208 of this title shall include regulations governing the management and operation of the Youth Program, including criteria for admission to the Youth Program.
Regulations establishing criteria for admission to the Youth Program shall:

subparagraph.text: be consistent with this title and any other statutory requirements; and
include criteria regarding:

sub-subparagraph.text: the individual’s age;
the individual’s mental and physical condition;
the individual’s amenability to treatment in the Youth Program;
the nature of the individual’s crime and the individual’s participation in the crime; and
the public safety.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Pretrial Detention and Services.
“Division” means the Division of Pretrial Detention and Services.
The creation of the Division is based on the findings and policies set forth in this section.

paragraph.text: Each year a large number of individuals have criminal charges placed against them in Baltimore City and remain on pretrial status until these charges are adjudicated.
Many of the individuals on pretrial status were formerly committed to the Baltimore City Jail.

subsection.text: There is an important public need to centralize and coordinate the provision of services to individuals on a pretrial status in Baltimore City.
Baltimore City does not have the financial resources to fund a local correctional facility at a level sufficient to meet the needs of those incarcerated.
The State recognizes the need to provide effective and efficient services to the public through management of the pretrial population in Baltimore City.
There is a Division of Pretrial Detention and Services in the Department.
The Division consists of:

paragraph.text: a Pretrial Release Services Program;
a Baltimore City Detention Center; and
a centralized booking facility for Baltimore City.

subsection.text: The Division has the same authority with regard to the custody of its inmates and the operation of the Baltimore City Detention Center as:

paragraph.text: the Division of Correction has under this Code with regard to the custody of its inmates and the operation of the Division of Correction; and
the sheriffs have under this Code with regard to the detention of inmates committed to their custody and the operation of local correctional facilities.

subsection.text: This title does not limit or supersede the authority of a court to determine the conditions of pretrial release.
With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a Commissioner of Pretrial Detention and Services.
The Commissioner serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
The Commissioner:

paragraph.text: has the same authority over the Division as this Code vests in the Commissioner of Correction over the Division of Correction;
shall keep safely any inmate committed or transferred to the custody of the Commissioner until the inmate is discharged in accordance with law;
is in charge of the Division, subject to the authority of the Secretary;
is the appointing authority for all employees of the Division;
shall establish a home detention program under terms and conditions that the Secretary provides;
may enter agreements with the Commissioner of Correction and governmental units for the housing of any inmate held in the Baltimore City Detention Center;
may enter agreements for the housing of any inmate committed to federal or local governmental units in the Baltimore City Detention Center; and
may enter other agreements necessary to carry out the purposes of this title.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection and notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Commissioner shall establish by regulation the terms and conditions of the home detention program required under subsection (c)(5) of this section.
The authority of a court to determine the conditions of pretrial release or to find that a defendant awaiting trial may not be placed on a home detention program may not be limited or superseded by:

subparagraph.text: a regulation of the Division or Department; or
the Division or the Commissioner.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Secretary, the Commissioner shall appoint a Deputy Commissioner of Pretrial Detention and Services.
The Deputy Commissioner serves at the pleasure of the Commissioner.
The Deputy Commissioner shall be the acting Commissioner in the absence of the Commissioner.
There is a Pretrial Release Services Program in the Division.

Subject to the authority of the Commissioner and in addition to any other duties established by law, the Pretrial Release Services Program shall perform the pretrial release duties formerly performed by the Pretrial Release Services Division of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, the Pretrial Release Committee, and the Division of Parole and Probation.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the Secretary, the Commissioner shall appoint the Director and Deputy Director of the Pretrial Release Services Program.
The Director is the head of the Pretrial Release Services Program.
The Director and Deputy Director of the Pretrial Release Services Program serve at the pleasure of the Commissioner.
The Director and Deputy Director are entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: There is a Baltimore City Detention Center in the Division.
The Baltimore City Detention Center is a pretrial detention facility for inmates committed or transferred to the custody of the Commissioner.
The Secretary may authorize the housing in the Baltimore City Detention Center of any inmate held in custody under any unit in the Department.
With the approval of the Secretary, the Commissioner shall appoint a warden of the Baltimore City Detention Center.
The warden serves at the pleasure of the Commissioner.
Subject to the authority of the Commissioner and the Secretary, the warden is in charge of the Baltimore City Detention Center.
The Commissioner may appoint assistant wardens for the Baltimore City Detention Center as provided in the State budget.
An assistant warden serves at the pleasure of the Commissioner.
Subject to the authority of the Commissioner and the Secretary, in the absence of the warden, an assistant warden designated by the warden is in charge of the Baltimore City Detention Center.
The Division shall operate a centralized booking facility for Baltimore City.
The centralized booking facility shall include:

paragraph.text: pretrial release services;
District Court Commissioners;
an Office of the State’s Attorney for Baltimore City; and
Baltimore City Police Services.

subsection.text: The centralized booking facility or the Baltimore City Detention Center shall be equipped for video bail review.
An inmate in the Baltimore City Detention Center who is sick, injured, or disabled shall:

paragraph.text: reimburse the State, as appropriate, for the payment of medical expenses; and
provide the warden with any information relating to:

subparagraph.text: the existence of any health insurance, group health plan, or prepaid medical care coverage under which the inmate is insured or covered;
the inmate’s eligibility for benefits under the Maryland Medical Assistance Program;
the name and address of the third party payor; and
any policy or other identifying number relating to items (i) through (iii) of this item.

paragraph.text: In addition to obtaining any reimbursement authorized under subsection (a) of this section and subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, the Department shall establish a reasonable fee, not to exceed $4, for each visit by an inmate to an institutional medical unit or noninstitutional physician, dentist, or optometrist.
The per visit fee shall be deducted from an inmate’s spending financial account, reserve financial account, or similar account held by the warden on behalf of the inmate.
The fees collected under this subsection shall be deposited in the General Fund of the State.
This subsection does not apply to a visit by an inmate to a medical unit or a physician, dentist, or optometrist if the visit is:

subparagraph.text: required as a part of the intake process;
required for an initial physical examination;
due to a referral by a nurse or physician’s assistant;
provided during a follow-up visit that is initiated by a medical professional from the Baltimore City Detention Center;
initiated by a medical or mental health staff member of the Baltimore City Detention Center; or
required for necessary treatment.

subsection.text: Subsections (a) and (b) of this section do not impose liability for reimbursement or payment of medical expenses on any person other than an inmate personally or through a person that provides insurance, coverage, or other benefits described under subsection (a) of this section.

On the recommendation of a health care provider, the warden of the Baltimore City Detention Center and the warden’s designees may authorize medical treatment of a juvenile inmate when in the judgment of the warden or a designee the treatment is required and a parent, guardian, or person in loco parentis of the juvenile is not available on a timely basis to give the authorization.
The warden or the warden’s designees may not be held liable for authorizing medical treatment under this section in good faith.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means the Maryland Parole Commission.
“Crime of violence” has the meaning stated in § 14-101 of the Criminal Law Article.
“Director” means the Director of the Division or the Director’s designee.
“Division” means the Division of Parole and Probation.
“Mandatory supervision” has the meaning stated in § 7-101 of this article.
“Offender” means an individual on parole or under mandatory supervision.
“Parolee” means an individual who has been released on parole.
“Program” means a home detention program established under § 6-108 of this subtitle.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: an inmate retained in the custody of the Patuxent Institution for:

subparagraph.text: examination to determine if the inmate is an eligible person, as defined in § 4-101 of this article; or
confinement as an eligible person under Title 4 of this article; or

paragraph.text: a juvenile committed to the jurisdiction of the Department of Juvenile Services or an institution or facility under its jurisdiction.

section.text: There is a Division of Parole and Probation in the Department.

subsection.text: Subject to the authority of the Secretary and in addition to any other duties established by law, the Division:

paragraph.text: shall:

subparagraph.text: supervise the conduct of parolees;
supervise an individual under mandatory supervision until the expiration of the individual’s maximum term or terms of confinement;
regularly inform the Commission of the activities of offenders who are supervised by the Division;

issue a warrant for the retaking of an offender charged with a violation of a condition of parole or mandatory supervision, if this authority is delegated by the Commission to the Director of the Division; and
administer the Drinking Driver Monitor Program, collect supervision fees, and adopt guidelines for collecting the monthly program fee assessed in accordance with § 6-115 of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: may recommend:

subparagraph.text: that the Commission modify any condition of parole or mandatory supervision; and
that the Commission issue a warrant for the retaking of an offender.

subsection.text: Funding for the Drinking Driver Monitor Program shall be as provided in the State budget.
With the approval of the Governor and the advice and consent of the Senate, the Secretary shall appoint the Director.
The Director is the head of the Division.
Before taking office, the appointee shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.
The Director serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
The Director is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.
There is a Warrant Apprehension Unit in the Division of Parole and Probation.
The Director may authorize parole and probation employees of the Warrant Apprehension Unit to:

paragraph.text: execute warrants for the retaking of offenders;
execute warrants for the arrest of probationers for whom a warrant is issued for an alleged violation of probation;
obtain and execute search warrants as authorized under § 6–109 of this subtitle; and
arrest offenders in the program as authorized under § 2–207 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

subsection.text: A parole and probation employee who is authorized to make arrests under this section shall:

paragraph.text: meet the minimum qualifications required by the Maryland Police Training Commission; and
complete satisfactorily the training prescribed by the Maryland Police Training Commission.

subsection.text: A parole and probation employee who is authorized to make arrests under this section may also exercise the powers of a peace officer and police officer.

section.text: A sheriff or police officer authorized to serve criminal process or a parole and probation employee designated under § 6-106 of this subtitle who receives a warrant for the retaking of an alleged violator shall execute the warrant in accordance with the directions in the warrant.

subsection.text: With the Secretary’s approval, the Director may establish a home detention program under which an offender may live in a private dwelling that the Director approves.
An offender in the program shall be supervised by means of:

paragraph.text: electronic devices; and
direct contact by employees of the Division.

subsection.text: An offender is not eligible for the program if a violation of a condition of parole or mandatory supervision is based on the commission of a crime of violence.
While in the program, an offender must remain in the offender’s approved dwelling except:

paragraph.text: with the approval of the Director, to go directly to and from:

subparagraph.text: the offender’s approved place of employment;
a medical or mental health treatment facility; or
offices of the Department;

paragraph.text: as required by legitimate medical or other emergencies; or
as otherwise allowed or directed by the Director.
An offender in the program is responsible for all of the offender’s living expenses, including those for food, clothing, medical care, shelter, and utilities.
Unless otherwise allowed by the Commission, as a condition of participation in the program, an offender shall make any court ordered payments for the support of dependents.

After determining the amount of reasonable payments necessary to satisfy court ordered restitution, fines, court costs, and other fees that are legally collectible, the Division shall establish a reasonable fee for the cost of electronic monitoring and, except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, collect the fee from each offender in the program.
If the Division determines that an offender cannot afford to pay the fee established under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Division may exempt the offender wholly or partly from the fee.

subsection.text: An offender in the program is not an agent or employee of the Division.
The Director shall employ parole and probation employees to supervise offenders in the program.
The Commission may remove an offender from the program at any time and for any reason.

paragraph.text: With the Secretary’s approval, the Director shall adopt regulations to implement the program.
Notwithstanding § 10-101(g)(2)(i) of the State Government Article, the regulations shall be adopted in accordance with the requirements of Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: The Director may apply to a judge of the District Court or a circuit court for a search warrant to enter the approved dwelling of an offender in the program to search for the offender.
An application for a search warrant shall:

paragraph.text: be in writing;
be verified by the applicant; and
describe the premises to be searched and the nature, scope, and purpose of the search.

subsection.text: A judge who receives an application for a search warrant may issue a warrant on a finding that:

paragraph.text: the scope of the proposed search is reasonable; and
obtaining consent to enter the premises may jeopardize the attempt to take custody of the offender.
A search warrant issued under this section shall specify the location of the premises to be searched.
A search conducted in accordance with a search warrant issued under this section may not exceed the limits specified in the warrant.

subsection.text: A search warrant issued under this section shall be executed and returned to the issuing judge:

paragraph.text: within the period specified in the warrant, which may not exceed 30 days from the date of issuance; or
within 15 days after the warrant is issued, if no period is specified in the warrant.

section.text: Each duly qualified parole agent of the Division has visitorial powers over any correctional facility in which an inmate is confined on a criminal charge, whether the correctional facility is operated by the State or by a county or municipal corporation of the State.

If a court suspends the sentence of an individual convicted of a crime and orders the individual to continue under the supervision of the Division for a specified time or until ordered otherwise, the Division shall:

paragraph.text: supervise the conduct of the individual;
determine whether the individual is complying with the conditions of probation or suspension of sentence; and
report to the court on the individual’s compliance.
On request of a court, a parole and probation agent of the Division shall:

subparagraph.text: provide the court with a presentence investigation report;
conduct other investigations; and
perform other probationary services.

paragraph.text: Except on court order, a presentence investigation report is confidential and is not available for public inspection.
On request, a presentence investigation report shall be made available to:

subparagraph.text: the defendant;
the defendant’s attorney;
the State’s Attorney;
a correctional facility;
a parole, probation, or pretrial release official of this State, any other state, or the United States;

a public or private mental health facility located in this State or any other state if the individual who is the subject of the report has been committed, or is being evaluated for commitment, to the facility for treatment as a condition of probation; or

a community substance abuse treatment provider located in this State or any other state if the individual who is the subject of the report will be treated or evaluated for treatment by the provider as a condition of probation.

paragraph.text: If a circuit court is satisfied that a presentence investigation report would help the sentencing process, the court may order the Division to complete a report before:

subparagraph.text: sentencing a defendant who is convicted of a felony or of a misdemeanor that resulted in serious physical injury or death to the victim to the jurisdiction of the Division of Correction; or
referring a defendant to the Patuxent Institution.

paragraph.text: The party that requests the report has the burden of establishing that the investigation should be ordered.
If required under § 11-402 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the report shall include a victim impact statement.

If the defendant has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor that is related to the defendant’s membership in a criminal gang, as defined in § 9-801 of the Criminal Law Article, the report may include information regarding the group affiliation of the defendant.

The Division shall complete a presentence investigation report in each case in which the death penalty or imprisonment for life without the possibility of parole is requested under § 2-202 or § 2-203 of the Criminal Law Article.
The report shall include a victim impact statement as provided under § 11-402 of the Criminal Procedure Article.
The court or jury before which the separate sentencing proceeding is conducted under § 2-303 or § 2-304 of the Criminal Law Article shall consider the report.

section.text: The Division and the Division of Correction shall keep the report submitted under § 15–105 of the Criminal Procedure Article on file so that each unit has an abstract of each case for which application for parole may be made under this article.

subsection.text: The Division may establish a citizens’ support unit to be known as “GUIDE”, which stands for: give understanding, inspiration, direction, and encouragement.
The unit shall consist of residents of the State who volunteer their time and services to aid in the education and counseling of parolees and probationers.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Program fee” means any fee the Division assesses on a supervisee the Division places in the Drinking Driver Monitor Program.
“Supervisee” means a person that the court places under the supervision of the Division.
“Supervision fee” means the fee the court orders under § 6-226 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

subsection.text: All supervisees placed in the Drinking Driver Monitor Program by the Division shall be:

paragraph.text: subject to a monthly supervision fee in accordance with § 6–226 of the Criminal Procedure Article; and
assessed a monthly program fee of $55 by the Division.
The Program fee imposed under this section shall be paid to the Division by all supervisees in the Drinking Driver Monitor Program.
The Division shall pay the Program fees collected under this section into the Drinking Driver Monitor Program Fund.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the Division may exempt a supervisee as a whole or in part from the Program fee imposed under this section if:

paragraph.text: the supervisee has diligently tried but has been unable to obtain employment that provides sufficient income for the supervisee to pay the fee;

subparagraph.text: the supervisee is a student in a school, college, or university or is enrolled in a course of vocational or technical training designed to prepare the student for gainful employment; and
certification of student status is supplied to the Division by the institution in which the supervisee is enrolled;

paragraph.text: the supervisee has a handicap limiting employment, as determined by a physical or psychological examination accepted by the Division;
the supervisee is responsible for the support of dependents and the payment of the fee is an undue hardship on the supervisee; or
other extenuating circumstances exist.

subsection.text: There is a Drinking Driver Monitor Program Fund.
The Fund shall be used for all costs of the Drinking Driver Monitor Program.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: the program fees paid by supervisees in the Drinking Driver Monitor Program; and
investment earnings of the Fund.

subsection.text: The money of the Fund shall be invested in the same manner as other State money.
Expenditures from the Fund may be made only:

paragraph.text: in accordance with the State budget; or
by the budget amendment procedure as provided in § 7-209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The Fund is subject to audit by the Office of Legislative Audits under § 2-1220 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Abatement” means an end to active supervision of a supervised individual, without effect on the legal expiration date of the case or the supervised individual’s obligation to:

subparagraph.text: obey all laws;
report as instructed; and
obtain written permission from the Division of Parole and Probation before relocating the supervised individual’s residence outside the State.

paragraph.text: “Earned compliance credit” means a 20–day reduction from the period of active supervision of the supervised individual for every month that a supervised individual:

subparagraph.text: exhibits full compliance with the conditions, goals, and treatment as part of the supervised individual’s probation, parole, or mandatory release supervision, as determined by the Department;
has no new arrests;
has not violated any conditions of no contact imposed on the supervised individual;
is current on court ordered payments for restitution, fines, and fees relating to the offense for which earned compliance credits are being accrued; and
is current in completing any community supervision requirements included in the conditions of the supervised individual’s probation, parole, or mandatory release supervision.
