subparagraph.text: after an administrative hearing, cancel any earned diminution of an inmate’s term of confinement if the inmate violates a regulation adopted under this section.
The Administrator shall adopt regulations to conduct each program.
In adopting the regulations, the Administrator shall consider the safety of the public and the security of a local correctional facility.

Except as provided in subsection (g)(2) of this section, if a condition of the sentence imposed by a court on an inmate is inconsistent with a regulation adopted under this subsection, the condition imposed by the court controls as to that inmate.

paragraph.text: While not released from confinement under the terms of a program, each participant shall be confined in a local correctional facility.

subparagraph.text: The Administrator or Administrator’s designee shall collect each participant’s total earnings, less payroll deductions.
From the participant’s earnings, the Administrator or designee shall pay:

sub-subparagraph.text: voluntary or court-ordered payments for support of a dependent; and
court-ordered payments for restitution.

subparagraph.text: The Administrator may:

sub-subparagraph.text: deduct a reasonable fee from the earnings of each inmate participating in the program; or
waive or reduce the fee.

subparagraph.text: The Administrator or designee shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: credit to the participant’s account any remaining balance; and
dispose of the balance as requested by the participant and as approved by the Administrator.

paragraph.text: A participant who knowingly violates a regulation adopted under this section:

subparagraph.text: is subject to removal from the program;
after an administrative hearing, is subject to cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement; and
is subject to the provisions of § 11-726 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Administrator may:

subparagraph.text: establish a pretrial release program that offers alternatives to pretrial detention; and
adopt regulations to carry out the program.

paragraph.text: A court may order an individual to participate in the pretrial release program if the individual appears before the court after being charged and detained on bond.
The court may enter the order at the imposition of bond, on review of bond, or any other time during the individual’s pretrial detention.

At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the sentencing judge or the Administrator may allow an individual who is convicted of a crime and sentenced to imprisonment to participate in a program established under subsection (e) of this section, provided that the individual meets the eligibility criteria established by the Administrator for participation in that program.
Subject to the eligibility criteria established by the Administrator, a judge may order that an individual participate in a program established under subsection (e) of this section.

The Administrator may not allow an individual to participate in a program established under subsection (e) of this section if a court order prohibits the individual from participating in that program.

A court may require an individual who is convicted of a crime to satisfy a fine or court costs by participating in a work program established under the jurisdiction of the Division of Parole and Probation.
An individual who participates in the work program shall receive credit of at least the federal minimum wage per hour toward the fine and court costs.

subsection.text: If the Administrator establishes and operates a community service program authorized by §§ 8-701 through 8-711 of this article, the Administrator may charge a reasonable fee to each individual participating in the program.
In this section, “Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Pretrial Detention and Services.
This section applies only in Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may allow an inmate of the Baltimore City Detention Center to participate in one of the activities specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection during the period of custody if the participation:

subparagraph.text: is approved by the judge ordering confinement or, if that judge is unable to act, by another judge of the committing court; and
is in accordance with available programs.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (1) of this subsection, an inmate may:

subparagraph.text: continue regular employment;
obtain new employment;
participate in a training, rehabilitation, or other special program; or
attend an educational institution.
An inmate who is authorized to participate in a program under this subsection shall be held in custody between program hours or periods.

The Commissioner or Commissioner’s designee may allow an inmate who is authorized to participate in a program under this subsection to be held in custody through home detention by the use of electronic monitoring devices.

Subject to the availability of funds, the Commissioner may contract for halfway houses or other suitable housing facilities or electronic monitoring devices for inmates authorized to participate in a program under this subsection.

paragraph.text: An inmate who is employed under a work release program shall surrender to the Commissioner or Commissioner’s designee the total earnings of the inmate under the program, less payroll deductions required by law.
From the net earnings of the inmate, the Commissioner or Commissioner’s designee shall deduct in the following order of priority:

subparagraph.text: an amount not to exceed one-third of the inmate’s net earnings for the cost to the State of providing food, lodging, electronic monitoring devices, and clothing for the inmate;
the actual and necessary food, travel, and other expenses of the inmate when released from actual custody under the program;
the amount, if any, that the inmate is legally obligated to pay for the support of a dependent by court order directed to the Commissioner; and
the amount for court-ordered payments for restitution.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner or Commissioner’s designee shall pay any amount deducted as required by paragraph (2)(iii) of this subsection as the court order directs.
The Commissioner or Commissioner’s designee shall:

subparagraph.text: credit to the inmate’s account any remaining balance; and
pay the balance in the inmate’s account to the inmate on release.

paragraph.text: If any part of the inmate’s final earnings under a work release program are required to satisfy the deductions specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the balance of the final earnings shall be forwarded to the inmate within 15 days after the date of release from the Baltimore City Detention Center.

A court may require an individual who is convicted of a crime to satisfy a fine or court costs by participating in a work program established under the jurisdiction of the Division of Parole and Probation in Baltimore City.
An individual who participates in the work program shall receive a credit of at least the federal minimum wage per hour toward the fine or court costs.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administrator” means the Administrator of the Baltimore County detention facilities or the Administrator’s designee.
“Leave” means authorized time away from a Baltimore County detention facility.
“Participant” means an inmate in a Baltimore County detention facility who participates in a program under this section.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Baltimore County.

paragraph.text: The Administrator may establish and administer a work release program.
If the Administrator establishes a work release program, the Administrator shall establish:

subparagraph.text: eligibility criteria for participation in the program; and
for each participant, a work release plan that includes the terms and conditions of the work release and employment.

paragraph.text: Participation in the work release program is a privilege authorized by court.
This section does not create a right to participate in the work release program or to remain in the program after the participant has been suspended or removed from the program.

subsection.text: The Administrator may recommend to a court that an individual participate in the work release program if:

paragraph.text: the individual has applied to participate in the program; and
the Administrator has approved the application.

subsection.text: If the Administrator recommends participation in the work release program, a court may authorize an individual to participate in the program:

paragraph.text: when the court imposes a sentence;
when the court commits an individual to the custody of a Baltimore County detention facility; or
at any time during the individual’s confinement.
The Administrator may suspend or remove a participant from the work release program:

subparagraph.text: at any time;
without prior approval from the court; and
for any reason that the Administrator determines.

paragraph.text: The Administrator shall notify the court within 15 days after the Administrator suspends or removes a participant from the work release program.
The Administrator shall collect each participant’s total earnings, less payroll deductions.
From the participant’s earnings, the Administrator:

subparagraph.text: may pay the reasonable cost to the county of providing food, lodging, and clothing for the participant;
may make court-ordered payments for dependents;
may pay court-ordered costs, fines, and restitution;
if ordered by the court, may reimburse the State for the court-appointed counsel; and
if ordered by the court, may reimburse the State for the services of the public defender.

paragraph.text: Any balance that remains after payments are made under paragraph (2) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall be credited to an account held by the Administrator for the participant; and
if the Administrator approves, shall be disposed of as requested by the participant.

paragraph.text: Any balance remaining in the participant’s account when the participant is released from the detention facility shall be paid to the participant.

subsection.text: A participant employed in the community under this section is not an agent or employee of Baltimore County, the Administrator, any judicial officer, or any other public officer of the county or State.

The Administrator may charge a participant a reasonable fee in an amount not to exceed the actual costs incurred by the county for food, travel, and other expenses related to the participant’s participation in the work release program.

paragraph.text: The Administrator may establish and administer a home detention program.
If the Administrator establishes a home detention program, the Administrator:

subparagraph.text: shall establish eligibility criteria for participation in the program; and
for each participant, shall establish a home detention plan that includes the terms and conditions of the home detention.

paragraph.text: Participation in the home detention program is a privilege authorized by court.
This section does not create a right to participate in the home detention program or to remain in the program after the participant has been suspended or removed from the program.

subsection.text: The Administrator may recommend to a court that an individual participate in the home detention program if:

paragraph.text: the individual has applied to participate in the program;

except for a violation of the Transportation Article or other traffic law or ordinance for which a penalty of incarceration is not authorized, the individual has no other charges pending in any municipal corporation, county, or state; and
the Administrator has approved the application.

subsection.text: If the Administrator recommends participation in the home detention program, a court may authorize an individual to participate in the program:

paragraph.text: after imposing a sentence; or
at any time during the individual’s confinement.
The Administrator may suspend or remove a participant from the home detention program:

subparagraph.text: at any time;
without prior approval from the court; and
for any reason that the Administrator determines.

paragraph.text: The Administrator shall notify the court within 15 days after the Administrator suspends or removes a participant from the home detention program.

subsection.text: A participant is not eligible for the home detention program if the participant:

paragraph.text: is serving a sentence for a crime of violence; or
has been found guilty of:

subparagraph.text: child abuse under § 3-601 or § 3-602 of the Criminal Law Article; or
escape under § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: The Administrator may charge a reasonable fee for the actual cost of electronic supervision and other administrative costs of the program.
The Administrator may adopt regulations to carry out this section.
This section applies only in Calvert County.

paragraph.text: At the time of sentencing or on a hearing of a motion for reconsideration of sentence, the court may sentence an individual who has been convicted of a crime to participate for a fixed period in the work release program at the Calvert County Detention Center.
After an inmate enters the work release program, the sentencing judge or, if the sentencing judge is unable to act, the judge of any court in the County may:

subparagraph.text: order the release of the inmate from custody; and
consider the supervisor’s recommendations and report of the inmate’s performance in making a determination to release the inmate.

paragraph.text: Subject to the directives and orders of the courts in the County, the supervisor of the County work release program shall establish and administer the work release program.
During reasonable hours, an inmate in the work release program may leave confinement to:

subparagraph.text: work at gainful employment;
participate in an outside counseling or rehabilitative program; or
obtain other services that the supervisor of the program considers necessary.
An inmate who is employed in accordance with this subsection shall surrender to the supervisor of the program the inmate’s total earnings, less payroll deductions required by law.
From the earnings of the inmate, the supervisor shall deduct and disburse in the following order of priority:

sub-subparagraph.text: food costs to the County;
lodging costs to the County;
travel costs to the County;
fines and costs imposed by the court;
amounts that the inmate is obligated to pay for support of a dependent; and
court-ordered payments for restitution.

subparagraph.text: The supervisor of the program may assist in the financial management of the inmate’s other bills and debts.
The supervisor of the program shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: credit to the inmate’s account any remaining balance; and
pay the balance in the inmate’s account to the inmate on final release from confinement.

paragraph.text: An inmate employed in the community under this subsection is not an agent or employee of the County, the Sheriff, any judicial officer, or any public officer of the County.
An inmate who violates a trust or a condition that the supervisor establishes for conduct and employment is subject to:

subparagraph.text: removal from the program; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “Program” means the Community Services Alternative Sentencing Program.
There is a Community Services Alternative Sentencing Program in the County Department of Public Safety.
The Program shall administer community service projects for individuals who are convicted of an offense and are referred to the Program by a court.
The County Commissioners may charge a reasonable fee to individuals who participate in the Program to help defray Program expenses.

subparagraph.text: An individual who is sentenced to participate in the substance abuse treatment program at the County treatment facility shall pay a per diem fee in an amount that the court determines to cover food, lodging, clothing, and other expenses incidental to participation in the treatment program.
A court may waive part or all of the fee based on an individual’s ability to pay.

paragraph.text: The County attorney may bring a civil action to collect any arrearage incidental to the per diem charge that remains unpaid 30 days after the individual’s discharge from the County treatment facility.
The Sheriff may:

subparagraph.text: establish a pretrial release program that offers alternatives to pretrial detention; and
adopt regulations to administer the program.

paragraph.text: A court may order an individual to participate in the pretrial release program if the individual:

subparagraph.text: appears before the court after being charged and detained on bond; and
meets the eligibility requirements of paragraph (4) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The court may make the order at the imposition of bond, on review of bond, or any other time during the individual’s pretrial detention.
An individual is eligible for the pretrial release program if the individual:

subparagraph.text: is recommended to the court for placement in the program by the program staff;
has no other charges for a felony or a violation of a crime of violence as defined in § 14-101 of the Criminal Law Article pending in any jurisdiction; and
is not in detention for or been previously convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a crime of violence listed in § 14-101 of the Criminal Law Article;
a felony; or
the crime of escape under § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Caroline County.
While confined in the Caroline County Jail, an inmate employed under § 11-602 of this title shall pay:

paragraph.text: court-ordered payments for restitution; and
the cost of the inmate’s food, lodging, and clothing.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners shall:

paragraph.text: establish the per diem rate for an inmate’s food, lodging, and clothing; and
designate an agent to collect the costs specified in this section.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Carroll County.
In this section, “crime of violence” has the meaning stated in § 14–101 of the Criminal Law Article.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff may:

subparagraph.text: establish a pretrial release program that offers alternatives to pretrial detention; and
adopt regulations to administer the program.

paragraph.text: A court may order an individual to participate in the pretrial release program if the individual:

subparagraph.text: appears before the court after being charged and detained on bond; and
meets the eligibility requirements of paragraph (4) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The court may make the order at the imposition of bond, on review of bond, or any other time during the individual’s pretrial detention.
An individual is eligible for the pretrial release program if the individual:

subparagraph.text: has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction for a crime of violence; and
is not in detention for:

sub-subparagraph.text: a crime of violence; or
the crime of escape under § 9–404 of the Criminal Law Article.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff may:

subparagraph.text: collect from each individual participating in the pretrial release program a reasonable fee for the cost of supervision and administration of the program; or
waive or reduce the fee.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff’s Office may establish a work release program.
At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the court may sentence the individual to participate in the work release program if the individual:

subparagraph.text: has been sentenced to the custody of the Sheriff; and
has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction for a crime of violence.

paragraph.text: An inmate who has been sentenced to participate in the work release program may continue regular employment or obtain new employment.

On approval of the Sheriff or Warden, an inmate who has been sentenced to the Carroll County Detention Center may leave the Detention Center to work, seek employment, obtain medical services, or participate in educational, rehabilitative, or training programs.
An inmate who has been sentenced to the Carroll County Detention Center shall be confined to the Detention Center:

subparagraph.text: except as provided in this subsection; or
unless a court orders otherwise.

paragraph.text: An inmate who is employed under the work release program shall:

subparagraph.text: reimburse the Sheriff’s Office for:

sub-subparagraph.text: the estimated cost to the Sheriff’s Office of food and lodging for the inmate; and
estimated expenses incurred by the Sheriff’s Office because of the participation of the inmate in the program; and

subparagraph.text: pay to the Sheriff court–ordered payments for restitution.

paragraph.text: An inmate who violates a condition or provision of trust that a court, the Sheriff, or Sheriff’s designee establishes is subject to:

subparagraph.text: removal from the work release program; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff shall:

subparagraph.text: establish and administer a home detention program; and
adopt regulations for the home detention program.

paragraph.text: At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the sentencing judge may require an individual who is convicted of a crime and sentenced to imprisonment under the custody of the Sheriff to participate in the home detention program.
Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, an inmate is eligible for the home detention program if:

subparagraph.text: the sentencing judge recommends the inmate for sentencing to the home detention program; and
the inmate has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: An inmate is not eligible for the home detention program if the inmate:

subparagraph.text: is serving a sentence for a crime of violence; or
has been found guilty of the crime of:

sub-subparagraph.text: child abuse under § 3–601 or § 3–602 of the Criminal Law Article; or
escape under § 9–404 of the Criminal Law Article.

paragraph.text: While participating in the home detention program, an inmate is responsible for:

subparagraph.text: medical care and related expenses; and
costs of clothes, food, lodging, restitution, taxes, and transportation.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff may:

subparagraph.text: collect from each inmate participating in the home detention program a reasonable fee for the cost of electronic supervision and administration of the program; or
waive or reduce the fee.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff may limit the number of inmates in the home detention program.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Cecil County.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff shall:

subparagraph.text: establish and administer a home detention program; and
adopt regulations to implement the program.
At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the sentencing judge may place the individual in the home detention program.
The Sheriff may place an inmate in the home detention program at any time after the inmate has served 25% of the inmate’s sentence.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, an inmate is eligible for the home detention program if the inmate:

subparagraph.text: is placed in the program by the sentencing judge or the Sheriff; and
has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: An inmate is not eligible for the home detention program if the inmate:

subparagraph.text: is serving a sentence for a crime of violence; or
has been found guilty of the crime of:

sub-subparagraph.text: child abuse under § 3-601 or § 3-602 of the Criminal Law Article; or
escape under § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff shall:

subparagraph.text: determine the amount of a reasonable fee for the cost of electronic supervision, including the administrative costs associated with the supervision; and
collect the fee from each inmate in the program.

subsection.text: In this section, “warden” means the warden of the Dorchester County Department of Corrections.
This section applies only in Dorchester County.
The County Commissioners may establish under the County Department of Corrections programs for:

paragraph.text: community service;
home detention;
pretrial release; and
work release.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners shall adopt regulations necessary to implement each program established under this section.
At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the court may allow the individual to participate in a program established under this section if the individual:

paragraph.text: is sentenced to the custody of the warden; and
has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction.

subsection.text: An inmate designated to participate in a program under this section may leave the detention center to:

paragraph.text: continue regular employment; or
seek new employment.
The warden or warden’s designee shall collect the earnings of an inmate designated to participate in a work release program, less any payroll deduction required by law.
From the earnings of the inmate, the warden shall deduct and disburse an amount that:

subparagraph.text: the warden determines to be a reasonable cost for providing food, lodging, and clothing for the inmate;
the County actually incurs for necessary food, travel, and other expenses incidental to the inmate’s participation in the program;
a court imposes for a fine, cost, or restitution;
the inmate is legally obligated to pay, or reasonably wants to pay, for support of a dependent; and
a court orders the inmate to repay to the State or the County for the services of an attorney appointed by the court.

paragraph.text: The warden shall:

subparagraph.text: credit to the inmate’s account any remaining balance; and
dispose of the balance in the inmate’s account as the individual reasonably requests and as the warden approves.

paragraph.text: If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that a court or the County Department of Corrections establishes for participation in a program under this section, the inmate is subject to:

subparagraph.text: removal from the program; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

paragraph.text: If a condition that a court imposes on an inmate is inconsistent with a regulation adopted under this section, the condition imposed by the court controls as to that inmate.

If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that the court or the County Department of Corrections establishes, the County Department of Corrections shall notify the sentencing court in writing of the violation.
The warden or warden’s designee may authorize compassionate leave under this subsection for any inmate committed to the County Department of Corrections:

subparagraph.text: to visit a seriously ill member of the inmate’s immediate family; or
to attend the viewing or funeral of a member of the inmate’s immediate family.

paragraph.text: An inmate who violates the terms of an authorization for compassionate leave is subject to the sanctions specified in subsection (h)(1) and (2) of this section.
An inmate who is granted compassionate leave under this subsection may be required to reimburse the County Department of Corrections for any expenses that the Department incurs in granting the leave.
The warden shall adopt regulations necessary to carry out this subsection.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Frederick County.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff shall:

subparagraph.text: establish a pretrial release program that offers alternatives to pretrial detention; and
adopt regulations to administer the program.

paragraph.text: A court may order an individual to participate in the pretrial release program, if the individual:

subparagraph.text: appears before the court after being charged and detained on bond; and
meets the eligibility requirements of paragraph (4) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The court may make the order at the imposition of bond, on review of bond, or any other time during the individual’s pretrial detention.
An individual is eligible for the pretrial release program if the individual:

subparagraph.text: is recommended to the court for placement in the program by the program staff;
has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction; and
is not in detention for:

sub-subparagraph.text: a crime of violence; or
the crime of escape under § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff’s Department may:

subparagraph.text: establish and direct a work release program; and
adopt guidelines for the operation of the program.

At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the sentencing judge may order that an individual participate in the work release program, subject to the guidelines adopted by the Sheriff.
If the sentencing judge is unable to act at the time of an inmate’s petition for work release, another judge of the committing court may order that the inmate participate in the work release program.

paragraph.text: In ordering an inmate to participate in the work release program, the court may allow the inmate to leave actual confinement to:

subparagraph.text: work at gainful, private employment;
seek gainful, private employment; or
participate in an educational, rehabilitative, or training program in the county.

paragraph.text: Unless the committing court directs otherwise, an inmate shall be confined in the detention center when not participating in the work release program.

subparagraph.text: The Sheriff or Sheriff’s designee shall collect the earnings of an inmate in the work release program, less payroll deductions required by law.
From the earnings of the inmate, the Sheriff shall deduct and disburse:

sub-subparagraph.text: an amount determined to be the cost to the county for food, lodging, and clothing for the inmate;
the actual cost of necessary food and travel and other expenses incidental to the inmate’s participation in the program;
any amount a court imposes for a fine, cost, or restitution;
any amount that the inmate is legally obligated or reasonably desires to pay for support of a dependent; and
if applicable, any amount that a court orders the inmate to repay to the State or to the county for the services of an attorney appointed by the court.

subparagraph.text: The Sheriff shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: credit to the inmate’s account the remaining balance; and
dispose of the balance in the inmate’s account as the inmate reasonably requests and as the Sheriff approves.

paragraph.text: If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that a judge or the Sheriff establishes for conduct or employment, after an administrative hearing that upholds the violation, the inmate is subject to:

subparagraph.text: removal from the work release program; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff shall:

subparagraph.text: establish and administer a home detention program; and
adopt regulations for the program.

paragraph.text: At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the sentencing judge may require that the individual participate in the home detention program.
An inmate is eligible for the home detention program if:

subparagraph.text: the sentencing judge recommended that the inmate participate in the program; and
the individual has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: An inmate is not eligible for the home detention program if the inmate:

subparagraph.text: is serving a sentence for a crime of violence; or
has been found guilty of the crime of:

sub-subparagraph.text: child abuse under § 3-601 or § 3-602 of the Criminal Law Article; or
escape under § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Garrett County.
The Board of County Commissioners and the Sheriff of Garrett County may establish and administer a home detention program and provide for other alternative sentencing options.
This section applies only in Harford County.

paragraph.text: At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the sentencing judge may allow an individual who is convicted of a crime and sentenced to imprisonment in a local correctional facility to participate in one of the activities specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection during the individual’s confinement.
An inmate who is allowed to do so under paragraph (1) of this subsection may:

subparagraph.text: continue regular employment;
obtain new employment;
participate in a training or rehabilitation program; or
attend an educational institution in the county.
The sentencing judge may require that the inmate comply with the terms and conditions that the judge considers appropriate.
The inmate’s participation in an authorized activity may not affect the length of the inmate’s sentence.

paragraph.text: The county government shall cooperate in and provide fiscal support for a work release program as provided under subsection (b) of this section.
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, an inmate of a local correctional facility who participates in the work release program may leave actual confinement:

subparagraph.text: at necessary and reasonable times, to work at gainful, private employment; or
under appropriate conditions, to seek gainful, private employment.

paragraph.text: Unless the committing court directs otherwise, an inmate shall be confined in the local correctional facility when not participating in the work release program.
An inmate who participates in the work release program shall surrender to the Sheriff:

subparagraph.text: a reasonable fee, as determined by the Sheriff, for the cost of providing food, lodging, and clothing for the inmate;
the actual cost of necessary food, travel, and other expenses incidental to the participation by the inmate in the program; and
court-ordered payments for restitution.

paragraph.text: If an inmate in the work release program violates a trust or a condition that the court establishes for conduct or employment, the inmate is subject to:

subparagraph.text: removal from the program; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff shall:

subparagraph.text: establish and administer a home detention program; and
adopt regulations for the program.

paragraph.text: At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the sentencing judge may allow an individual who is convicted of a crime and sentenced to imprisonment in a local correctional facility to participate in the home detention program.
Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, an inmate is eligible for the home detention program if:

subparagraph.text: the sentencing judge recommends that the inmate participate in the program; and
the inmate has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: An inmate is not eligible for the home detention program if the inmate:

subparagraph.text: is serving a sentence for a crime of violence; or
has been found guilty of the crime of:

sub-subparagraph.text: child abuse under § 3-601 or § 3-602 of the Criminal Law Article; or
escape under § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.

paragraph.text: In this section the following terms have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Howard County Department of Correction.
“Director” means the Director of the Howard County Department of Correction.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Howard County.

paragraph.text: The Department may establish a work release program.
The work release program may include an inmate’s participation in a program of employment, rehabilitation, training, education, or home detention.
The Director may adopt regulations relating to the operation of the work release program.

At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the sentencing judge if available, or otherwise the court may allow an individual to participate in the work release program if the individual:

subparagraph.text: has been sentenced to the custody of the Department; and
has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction for a crime of violence as defined under § 14–101(d) of the Criminal Law Article.

paragraph.text: If the Department approves, an inmate in the custody of the Howard County Detention Center may leave the Center to participate in a work release program.
An inmate who has been designated to participate in a work release program may:

subparagraph.text: continue regular employment; or
obtain new employment.

paragraph.text: An inmate who has been sentenced to the custody of the Department shall be confined to the Howard County Detention Center:

subparagraph.text: except as provided in this section; or
unless a court orders otherwise.

subsection.text: An inmate who is employed while in a work release program under this section shall:

paragraph.text: reimburse the Department by paying a fee based on:

subparagraph.text: the Department’s estimated cost of providing food and lodging to the inmate; and
the estimated expenses incurred by the Department because of the inmate’s participation in the work release program; and

paragraph.text: pay to the Director court–ordered payments for restitution.

subsection.text: An inmate employed in the community under this section is not an agent or employee of the county, the Director, the court or any judicial officer, or any public officer of the county.
An inmate who violates a condition or provision of trust that the court or the Department establishes is subject to:

paragraph.text: removal from the work release program; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

subsection.text: In this section, “warden” means the warden of the Kent County Detention Center.
This section applies only in Kent County.
The County Commissioners may establish under the Kent County Detention Center programs for:

paragraph.text: community service;
home detention;
pretrial release; and
work release.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners shall adopt regulations necessary to implement each program established under this section.
At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the court may allow an individual to participate in any program established under this section if the individual:

paragraph.text: is sentenced to the custody of the warden; and
has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction.

subsection.text: An inmate designated to participate in a program under this section may leave the Kent County Detention Center to:

paragraph.text: continue regular employment;
seek new employment; or
receive therapy for drug or alcohol addiction.
The warden or warden’s designee shall collect the earnings of an inmate designated to participate in a work release program, less any payroll deduction required by law.
From the earnings of the inmate, the warden shall deduct and disburse an amount:

subparagraph.text: the warden determines to be the cost to the county for providing food, lodging, and clothing for the inmate;
the county actually incurs for necessary food, travel, and other expenses incidental to participation by the inmate in the program;
a court imposes for a fine, cost, or restitution;
the inmate is legally obligated to pay, or reasonably wants to pay, for support of a dependent; and
a court orders the inmate to repay to the State or to the county for the services of an attorney appointed by the court.

paragraph.text: The warden shall:

subparagraph.text: credit to the inmate’s account any remaining balance; and
dispose of the balance in the inmate’s account as the inmate reasonably requests and as the warden approves.

paragraph.text: If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that the court or the Kent County Detention Center establishes for conduct or employment, the inmate is subject to:

subparagraph.text: removal from a program specified in subsection (c) of this section; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

paragraph.text: If a condition that a court imposes on an inmate is inconsistent with a regulation adopted under this section, the condition imposed by the court controls as to that inmate.
If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that a court or the detention center establishes, the Kent County Detention Center shall notify the sentencing court in writing of the violation.
Inmates of the Kent County Detention Center who are employed under § 11–602 of this title shall pay:

subparagraph.text: court–ordered payments for restitution; and
the reasonable cost of the food, lodging, and clothing of the inmate.

paragraph.text: The County Commissioners shall:

subparagraph.text: establish a reasonable per diem rate for the food, lodging, and clothing of an inmate; and
designate the warden as the agent to collect these costs.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the county may collect from an inmate who is sentenced to the Kent County Detention Center for nonconsecutive periods of 48 hours or less an amount determined to be the average cost to the county of providing food, lodging, and clothing for the inmate.
A court may waive any or all of the charge specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection.
The warden or warden’s designee may authorize compassionate leave under this subsection for any inmate committed to the Kent County Detention Center:

subparagraph.text: to visit a seriously ill member of the immediate family of the inmate; or
to attend a viewing or funeral of a member of the immediate family of the inmate.

paragraph.text: An inmate who is granted compassionate leave may be required to reimburse the Kent County Detention Center for any expenses that the detention center incurs in granting the leave.
The warden shall adopt regulations necessary to carry out this subsection.

subsection.text: In this section, “Director” means the Director of the Montgomery County Department of Correction and Rehabilitation.
This section applies only in Montgomery County.

paragraph.text: The County Council shall establish work release and prerelease programs in accordance with this section.

A work release or prerelease program shall provide that an inmate of the County Department of Correction and Rehabilitation, on approval of the Director, may leave confinement during necessary and reasonable hours to seek or work at gainful employment and to participate in other rehabilitative activities, including:

subparagraph.text: intensive counseling;
academic education;
home visitation;
transitional phased release programs; and
maximum use of other community resources or other similar rehabilitative activities.

paragraph.text: At any time during the confinement of an inmate of the County Department of Correction and Rehabilitation, the judge who ordered the confinement or, if that judge is unable to act, another judge of the committing court, may approve the transfer of the inmate to the work release/prerelease center to participate in a work release or prerelease program:

subparagraph.text: in accordance with the selection requirements and programs established by the County Council; and
after a recommendation by the Director or the Director’s designee.

paragraph.text: After the inmate enters the work release or prerelease program, the judge who ordered confinement or, if that judge is unable to act, another judge of the committing court, may order the release of the inmate from custody based on:

subparagraph.text: the recommendation of the Director or Director’s designee; and
the report of the inmate’s performance in the work release or prerelease program.

paragraph.text: When not employed or otherwise participating in a work release program, the inmate shall be confined in the prerelease center unless the committing court directs otherwise.
The Director or the Director’s designee shall collect the earnings of an inmate participating in a work release or prerelease program under this section, less any payroll deduction required by law.
From the earnings of the inmate, the Director may deduct:

subparagraph.text: the amount determined to be the cost to the county of providing food, lodging, and clothing for the inmate;
actual and necessary food, travel, and other expenses incidental to the inmate’s participation in the program;
an amount the inmate is legally obligated or desires to pay for the support of a dependent;
if applicable, a reasonable amount to repay the State or the county for an attorney appointed by the court; and
court–ordered payments for restitution.

paragraph.text: The Director shall:

subparagraph.text: credit to the inmate’s account any remaining balance; and
dispose of the balance in the inmate’s account as the inmate requests and the Director approves.

paragraph.text: If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that the County Council establishes for conduct or employment, the inmate is subject to:

subparagraph.text: removal from the program; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

paragraph.text: If an inmate violates a condition or a term of the program and the Director or the Director’s designee removes the inmate from the program because of the violation, a judge of the committing court may redesignate the Division of Correction as the agency of custody for the remaining term of the inmate’s confinement.

The County Department of Correction and Rehabilitation shall provide all work release, prerelease, and similar services to county residents who are sentenced to the jurisdiction of the Division of Correction.

The Commissioner of Correction may transfer to the County Department of Correction and Rehabilitation only those eligible individuals who are screened and recommended for approval for the work release or prerelease program, or both programs, by both correctional agencies.
The county facilities shall operate in accordance with general operational standards that the Commissioner of Correction approves.

The County Department of Correction and Rehabilitation and the Division of Correction shall negotiate a contract each year that provides for State reimbursement on a per diem basis for operational costs to the county for providing the community correctional services described in this section to inmates sentenced to the Division of Correction and confined in the County Department of Correction and Rehabilitation.

subsection.text: In this section, “administrator” means an administrator of a county detention center.
This section applies only in Prince George’s County.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, an administrator may allow an inmate sentenced to imprisonment in a detention center after being convicted of a crime or found in contempt of court to leave actual confinement to:

subparagraph.text: seek or work at gainful, private employment;
participate in a training or rehabilitation program; or
attend educational or vocational institutions in the county.

paragraph.text: The administrator may allow the inmate to leave confinement:

subparagraph.text: in accordance with established programs;
during necessary and reasonable hours; and
after determining that the inmate is eligible for the program and recommending it to and receiving written approval from the sentencing or administrative judge.

paragraph.text: The administrator shall adopt guidelines and rules for the conduct of the work release program that shall:

subparagraph.text: take into consideration the security of the detention center and the safety of the public; and
conform with conditions that a sentencing or administrative judge may impose in a particular case.

paragraph.text: When an inmate is not employed or otherwise participating in a work release program, the inmate shall be confined in the detention center in the same manner as any other inmate committed to the custody of the administrator.
If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that the administrator establishes in the rules for conduct or employment, the inmate is:

subparagraph.text: subject to removal from the work release program; and
after an administrative hearing, subject to cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

paragraph.text: The authorized representative of a detention center shall collect the earnings of an inmate, less any payroll deductions.
From the earnings of the inmate, the authorized representative of the detention center shall deduct:

subparagraph.text: the amount determined to be the cost to the county for food, lodging, and clothing for the inmate;
actual and necessary food, travel, and other expenses incidental to the inmate’s participation in the program;
an amount the inmate is legally obligated or desires to pay for the support of a dependent; and
court–ordered payments for restitution.

paragraph.text: The authorized representative of the detention center shall credit to the inmate’s account any remaining balance.
An administrator may develop educational and vocational programs to further the educational and vocational training of an inmate sentenced to the detention center.

subparagraph.text: The administrator shall adopt regulations to govern the conduct and participation of an inmate in an educational or vocational program as necessary for the security of the detention center and the safety of the public.
If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that the administrator establishes for conduct during participation in an educational or vocational program, the inmate:

sub-subparagraph.text: is subject to removal from the program, with notice to the sentencing judge; and
after an administrative hearing, is subject to cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Queen Anne’s County.
While confined in the Queen Anne’s County Jail, an inmate employed under § 11-602 of this title shall pay:

paragraph.text: court-ordered payments, including restitution payments; and
the reasonable cost of the food, lodging, and clothing of the inmate.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners shall:

paragraph.text: establish a reasonable per diem rate for the food, lodging, and clothing of an inmate; and
designate the Warden of the Queen Anne’s County Jail as the agent to collect the costs and payments specified in this section.

subsection.text: This section applies only in St. Mary’s County.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff may establish:

subparagraph.text: a home detention program; and
a work release program.
If the Sheriff establishes a program under this section, the Sheriff shall adopt regulations necessary to implement each program established.
If a condition that a court imposes on an inmate is inconsistent with a regulation adopted under this subsection, the condition imposed by the court controls as to that inmate.

paragraph.text: At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the court may allow the individual to participate in any program established under this section if the individual:

subparagraph.text: is sentenced to the custody of the Sheriff; and
has no other charges for a felony or a violation of a crime of violence as defined in § 14-101 of the Criminal Law Article pending in any jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: An inmate who is participating in any program established under this section and who is sentenced to the St. Mary’s County Detention Center may leave the detention center to:

subparagraph.text: continue regular employment;
seek new employment; or
attend any court-ordered treatment appointments.

subsection.text: The Sheriff and the Board of County Commissioners of St. Mary’s County may charge an inmate participating in the work release program a reasonable monetary amount or program participation fee to pay for the costs incurred by the county for providing the inmate with food, lodging, and clothing.

paragraph.text: If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that a court or Sheriff has established for participating in any program established under this section, the Sheriff or the Sheriff’s designee shall notify the court in writing of the violation.
An inmate who violates a trust or a condition that a court or Sheriff has established for participating in any program established under this section is subject to:

subparagraph.text: removal from the program; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Talbot County.
While confined in the Talbot County Jail, an inmate employed under § 11-602 of this title shall pay:

paragraph.text: court-ordered payments for restitution; and
the cost of the food, lodging, and clothing of the inmate.

subsection.text: The County Council shall:

paragraph.text: establish the per diem rate for the food, lodging, and clothing of an inmate; and
designate an agent to collect the costs specified in this section.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Washington County.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff shall:

subparagraph.text: establish and administer:

sub-subparagraph.text: a home detention program;
a work release program; and
a pretrial release program; and

subparagraph.text: adopt regulations necessary to implement each program established under this section.

paragraph.text: At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the court may allow an individual who is placed in the custody of the Sheriff to participate in any program established under this section.
Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, an inmate is eligible to participate in any program established under this section if the inmate:

subparagraph.text: is recommended for the program by the court; and
meets eligibility criteria set by the Sheriff.

paragraph.text: An inmate is not eligible to participate in any program established under this section if the inmate:

subparagraph.text: is incarcerated for or has been convicted previously of a crime of violence listed in § 14-101 of the Criminal Law Article; or
has been found guilty of the crime of:

sub-subparagraph.text: child abuse under § 3-601 or § 3-602 of the Criminal Law Article; or
escape under § 9-404 of the Criminal Law Article.

paragraph.text: While participating in any program established under this section an inmate is responsible for:

subparagraph.text: the inmate’s medical care and related expenses; and
costs of lodging, food, clothing, transportation, restitution, and taxes.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff may:

subparagraph.text: collect a reasonable fee from each inmate participating in any program established under this section; or
waive or reduce the fee.

paragraph.text: The Sheriff may determine the maximum number of inmates that may participate in any program established under this section.

An inmate who knowingly violates a term or a condition of any program established under this section is subject to the penalties provided under § 11-726 of this subtitle and to other disciplinary action provided by law.

subsection.text: In this section, “Director” means the Director of the Wicomico County Department of Corrections.
This section applies only in Wicomico County.
The County Council may establish under the County Department of Corrections programs for:

paragraph.text: community service;
home detention;
pretrial release; and
work release.

subsection.text: The County Council shall adopt regulations necessary to implement each program established under this section.
At the time of sentencing or at any time during an individual’s confinement, the court may allow the individual to participate in any program established under this section if the individual:

paragraph.text: is sentenced to the custody of the Director; and
has no other charges pending in any jurisdiction.

subsection.text: An inmate designated to participate in a program specified under subsection (c) of this section may leave the detention center to:

paragraph.text: continue regular employment; or
seek new employment.
The Director or Director’s designee, shall collect the earnings of an inmate designated to participate in a work release program, less any payroll deduction required by law.
From the earnings of the inmate, the Director shall deduct and disburse an amount:

subparagraph.text: the Director determines to be a reasonable cost for providing food, lodging, and clothing for the inmate;
the County actually incurs for necessary food, travel, and other expenses incidental to the inmate’s participation in the program;
a court imposes for a fine, cost, or restitution;
the inmate is legally obligated to pay, or reasonably desires to pay, for support of a dependent; and
a court orders the inmate to repay to the State or to the County for the services of an attorney appointed by a court.

paragraph.text: The Director shall:

subparagraph.text: credit to the inmate’s account any remaining balance; and
dispose of the balance in the inmate’s account as the inmate reasonably requests and as the Director approves.

paragraph.text: If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that a court or the County Department of Corrections has established for participation in a program specified in subsection (c) of this section, the inmate is subject to:

subparagraph.text: removal from the program; and
cancellation of any earned diminution of the inmate’s term of confinement.

paragraph.text: If a condition that a court imposes on an inmate is inconsistent with a regulation adopted under this section, the condition imposed by the court controls as to that inmate.

If an inmate violates a trust or a condition that a court or the County Department of Corrections establishes, the County Department of Corrections shall notify the sentencing court in writing of the violation.
The Director or the Director’s designee may authorize compassionate leave under this subsection for any inmate committed to the County Department of Corrections:

subparagraph.text: to visit a seriously ill member of the inmate’s immediate family; or
to attend the viewing or funeral of a member of the inmate’s immediate family.

paragraph.text: An inmate who violates the terms of an authorization for compassionate leave is subject to the sanctions specified in subsection (h)(1) of this section and § 11-726 of this subtitle.
An inmate who is granted compassionate leave under this subsection may be required to reimburse the Department for any expenses that the County Department of Corrections incurs in granting the leave.
The Director shall adopt regulations necessary to carry out this subsection.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Worcester County.
While confined in the Worcester County Jail, an inmate employed under § 11-602 of this title shall pay:

paragraph.text: court-ordered payments for restitution; and
the cost of the food, lodging, and clothing of the inmate.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners shall:

paragraph.text: establish the per diem rate for the food, lodging, and clothing of an inmate; and
designate an agent to collect the costs specified in this section.

subsection.text: An individual who knowingly violates a restriction on movement imposed as a condition of leave, work release, or a home detention order or agreement under this subtitle is guilty of escape as provided in §§ 9-404 through 9-407 of the Criminal Law Article.

An individual who knowingly violates any other condition of leave, work release, or a home detention order or agreement imposed under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
In this section, “weekend inmate” means an inmate sentenced to a local correctional facility for nonconsecutive periods of 48 hours or less per week.

The governing body of a county may impose on and collect from a weekend inmate a reasonable fee in an amount not to exceed the average cost of providing food, lodging, and clothing for an inmate for the time the inmate is confined in the local correctional facility.

If the governing body of a county imposes a fee under this section, the governing body shall adopt standard procedures to implement this section, including a procedure for the waiver of a part or all of the fee based on the ability of an inmate to pay the fee.

Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the managing official of a local correctional facility may designate correctional officers employed by the local correctional facility to have the power to make arrests as authorized by § 2-207(d) of the Criminal Procedure Article.

Correctional officers designated by a managing official to make arrests as authorized under § 2-207(d) of the Criminal Procedure Article shall meet the minimum qualifications and satisfactorily complete the training required by the Maryland Police Training Commission.
The managing official of a local correctional facility or the managing official’s designee may issue a retake warrant for the apprehension and return of an escapee.

If a managing official or managing official’s designee issues a retake warrant under subsection (a) of this section, the managing official or designee shall forward a copy of the retake warrant to the State’s Attorney for the county in which the escape occurred.

A sheriff or police officer who is authorized to serve criminal process and to whom a warrant issued under this section is delivered shall execute the warrant in accordance with the directions in the warrant.
A sheriff or police officer who makes an arrest under this section shall promptly notify the managing official, or managing official’s designee, who issued the warrant of the arrest.

section.text: In this subtitle, “fund” means an inmate welfare fund established under § 11-902 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Each local correctional facility may establish an inmate welfare fund.
A fund may be used only for goods and services that benefit the general inmate population as defined by regulations that the managing official of the local correctional facility adopts.

paragraph.text: Each fund is a special continuing, nonlapsing fund.

subparagraph.text: Each fund consists of:

sub-subparagraph.text: profits derived from the sale of goods through the commissary operation and telephone and vending machine commissions; and
subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, money received from other sources.

subparagraph.text: Money from the General Fund of the State or county, including any federal funds, may not be transferred by budget amendment or otherwise to a fund.
Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the chief financial officer for a county shall separately hold and shall account for each fund in the county.

The chief financial officer for Dorchester County or the managing official of the local correctional facility as designated by Dorchester County shall separately hold and shall account for each fund in Dorchester County.

paragraph.text: This section may not be construed to:

subparagraph.text: prohibit a periodic or special audit by the State, the federal government, or a county that provides funds for a local correctional facility; or
affect the calculation of reimbursement rates, as provided in § 9-403 of this article.

paragraph.text: Each fund shall be invested and reinvested in the same manner as other county funds.
Any investment earnings of a fund shall be credited to the fund.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the chief financial officer for the county shall pay out money from each fund as approved in the county budget.

The chief financial officer for Dorchester County or the managing official of the local correctional facility as designated by Dorchester County shall pay out money from the fund as approved in the county budget.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Correctional officer” has the meaning stated in § 8–201 of this article.

“Correctional officer” does not include an officer who is in probationary status on initial entry into the correctional agency except if an allegation of brutality in the execution of the officer’s duties is made against the officer.
“Hearing” means a proceeding during an investigation conducted by a hearing board to take testimony or receive other evidence.
“Hearing” does not include an interrogation at which no testimony is taken under oath.

subsection.text: “Hearing board” means a board that is authorized by the managing official to hold a hearing on a complaint against a correctional officer.
“Internal investigation unit” means the internal investigation unit of a correctional facility charged with the investigation of complaints within a correctional facility.

section.text: This subtitle applies only in Cecil County, Garrett County, and St. Mary’s County.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided, the provisions of this subtitle supersede any inconsistent provisions of any other State or local law that conflicts with this subtitle to the extent of the conflict.

This subtitle does not limit the authority of the managing official to regulate the competent and efficient operation and management of a county correctional facility by any reasonable means including transfer and reassignment if:

paragraph.text: that action is not punitive in nature; and
the managing official determines that action to be in the best interests of the internal management of the correctional facility.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a correctional officer has the same rights to engage in political activity as a State employee.
The right of a correctional officer to engage in political activity does not apply when the correctional officer is on duty or acting in an official capacity.

subsection.text: A managing official:

paragraph.text: may not prohibit secondary employment by a correctional officer; but
may adopt reasonable regulations that relate to secondary employment by a correctional officer.

subsection.text: A correctional officer may not be required or requested to disclose an item of the correctional officer’s property, income, assets, source of income, debts, or personal or domestic expenditures, including those of a member of the correctional officer’s family or household, unless:

paragraph.text: the information is necessary to investigate a possible conflict of interest with respect to the performance of the correctional officer’s official duties; or
the disclosure is required by federal or State law.

subsection.text: A correctional officer may not be discharged, disciplined, demoted, or denied promotion, transfer, or reassignment, or otherwise discriminated against in regard to the correctional officer’s employment or be threatened with that treatment because the correctional officer:

paragraph.text: has exercised or demanded the rights granted by this subtitle; or
has lawfully exercised constitutional rights.

subsection.text: A statute may not abridge and a correctional facility may not adopt a regulation that prohibits the right of a correctional officer to bring suit that arises out of the correctional officer’s duties as a correctional officer.
A correctional officer may waive in writing any or all rights granted by this subtitle.

The investigation or interrogation by an internal investigation unit of a correctional officer for a reason that may lead to disciplinary action, demotion, or dismissal shall be conducted in accordance with this section.

For purposes of this section, the investigating officer or interrogating officer shall be a sworn law enforcement or correctional official or an individual with former law enforcement or corrections experience.

paragraph.text: A complaint against a correctional officer that alleges brutality in the execution of the correctional officer’s duties may not be investigated unless the complaint is sworn to, before an official authorized to administer oaths, by:

subparagraph.text: the aggrieved individual;
a member of the aggrieved individual’s immediate family;
an individual with firsthand knowledge obtained because the individual was present at and observed the alleged incident; or
the parent or guardian of the minor child, if the alleged incident involves a minor child.

paragraph.text: Unless a complaint is filed within 90 days after the alleged brutality, an investigation that may lead to disciplinary action under this subtitle for brutality may not be initiated.
The correctional officer under investigation shall be informed of the name, rank, and command of:

subparagraph.text: the law enforcement or correctional official or other individual in charge of the investigation;
the interrogating official; and
each individual present during an interrogation.

paragraph.text: Before an interrogation, the correctional officer under investigation shall be informed in writing of the nature of the investigation.

subsection.text: If the correctional officer under interrogation is under arrest, or is likely to be placed under arrest as a result of the interrogation, the correctional officer shall be informed completely of all of the correctional officer’s rights before the interrogation begins.

Unless the seriousness of the investigation is of a degree that an immediate interrogation is required, the interrogation shall be conducted at a reasonable hour, preferably when the correctional officer is on duty.

paragraph.text: The interrogation shall take place:

subparagraph.text: at the office of the command of the investigating officer or at the office of the managing official of the correctional facility in which the incident allegedly occurred, as designated by the investigating official; or
at another reasonable and appropriate place.

paragraph.text: The correctional officer under investigation may waive the right described in paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection.

All questions directed to the correctional officer under interrogation shall be asked by and through one interrogating officer during any one session of interrogation consistent with paragraph (2) of this subsection.
Each session of interrogation shall:

subparagraph.text: be for a reasonable period; and
allow for personal necessities and rest periods as reasonably necessary.

subsection.text: The correctional officer under interrogation may not be threatened with transfer, dismissal, or disciplinary action.

subparagraph.text: On request, the correctional officer under interrogation has the right to be represented by counsel or another responsible representative of the correctional officer’s choice who shall be present and available for consultation at all times during the interrogation.
The correctional officer may waive the right described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph.
The interrogation shall be suspended for a period not exceeding 10 days until representation is obtained.
Within the 10–day period described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, the managing official, for good cause shown, may extend the period for obtaining representation.

paragraph.text: During the interrogation, the correctional officer’s counsel or representative may:

subparagraph.text: request a recess at any time to consult with the correctional officer;
object to any question posed; and
state on the record outside the presence of the correctional officer the reason for the objection.

paragraph.text: A complete record shall be kept of the entire interrogation, including all recess periods, of the correctional officer.
The record may be written, taped, or transcribed.

On completion of the investigation, and on request of the correctional officer under investigation or the correctional officer’s counsel or representative, a copy of the record of the interrogation shall be made available at least 10 days before a hearing.

The internal investigation unit may order the correctional officer under investigation to submit to blood alcohol tests, blood, breath, or urine tests for controlled dangerous substances, polygraph examinations, or interrogations that specifically relate to the subject matter of the investigation.

If the internal investigation unit orders the correctional officer to submit to a test, examination, or interrogation described in paragraph (1) of this subsection and the correctional officer refuses to do so, the internal investigation unit may commence an action that may lead to a punitive measure as a result of the refusal.

If the internal investigation unit orders the correctional officer to submit to a test, examination, or interrogation described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the results of the test, examination, or interrogation are not admissible or discoverable in a criminal proceeding against the correctional officer.

If the internal investigation unit orders the correctional officer to submit to a polygraph examination, the results of the polygraph examination may not be used as evidence in an administrative hearing unless the internal investigation unit and the correctional officer agree to the admission of the results.
The correctional officer’s counsel or representative need not be present during the actual administration of a polygraph examination by a certified polygrapher if:

subparagraph.text: the questions to be asked are reviewed with the correctional officer or the counsel or representative before the administration of the examination;
the counsel or representative is allowed to observe the administration of the examination; and

a copy of the final report of the examination by the certified polygrapher is made available to the correctional officer or the counsel or representative within a reasonable time, not exceeding 10 days, after completion of the examination.

paragraph.text: On completion of an investigation and at least 10 days before a hearing, the correctional officer under investigation shall be:

subparagraph.text: notified of the name of each witness and of each charge and specification against the correctional officer; and
provided with a copy of the investigatory file and any exculpatory information, if the correctional officer and the correctional officer’s representative agree to:

sub-subparagraph.text: execute a confidentiality agreement with the internal investigation unit not to disclose any material contained in the investigatory file and exculpatory information for any purpose other than to defend the correctional officer; and
pay a reasonable charge for the cost of reproducing the material.

paragraph.text: The internal investigation unit may exclude from the exculpatory information provided to a correctional officer under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: the identity of confidential sources;
nonexculpatory information; and
recommendations as to charges, disposition, or punishment.

paragraph.text: The internal investigation unit may not insert adverse material into a file of the correctional officer, except the file of the internal investigation, unless the correctional officer has an opportunity to review, sign, receive a copy of, and comment in writing on the adverse material.
The correctional officer may waive the right described in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A correctional officer who is denied a right granted by this subtitle may apply to the circuit court of the county where the correctional officer is regularly employed for an order that directs the internal investigation unit to show cause why the right should not be granted.
The correctional officer may apply for the show cause order:

paragraph.text: either individually or through the correctional officer’s certified or recognized employee organization; and
at any time prior to the beginning of a hearing by the hearing board.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, an internal investigation unit may not bring administrative charges against a correctional officer unless the unit files the charges within 1 year after the act that gives rise to the charges comes to the attention of the managing official.
The 1–year limitation of subsection (a) of this section does not apply to charges that relate to criminal activity or excessive force.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection and § 11–1012 of this subtitle, if the investigation or interrogation of a correctional officer results in a recommendation of demotion, dismissal, transfer, loss of pay, reassignment, or similar action that is considered punitive, the correctional officer is entitled to a hearing on the issues by a hearing board before the managing official takes that action.
A correctional officer who has been convicted of a felony is not entitled to a hearing under this section.
The internal investigation unit shall give notice to the correctional officer of the right to a hearing by a hearing board under this section.
The notice required under this subsection shall state the time and place of the hearing and the issues involved.
Except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection and in § 11–1012 of this subtitle, the hearing board authorized under this section shall consist of at least three members who:

subparagraph.text: are appointed by the managing official and chosen from correctional officers within that correctional facility, or from correctional officers of another correctional facility with the approval of the managing official of the other facility; and
have had no part in the investigation or interrogation of the correctional officer.

paragraph.text: At least one member of the hearing board shall be of the same rank as the correctional officer against whom the complaint is filed.

subparagraph.text: If the managing official is the correctional officer under investigation, the managing official of another correctional facility in the State shall function as the correctional officer of the same rank on the hearing board.

If the managing official of a correctional facility of a county or municipal corporation is under investigation, the official authorized to appoint the managing official’s successor shall select the managing official of another correctional facility to function as the correctional officer of the same rank on the hearing board.

A correctional facility or the facility’s superior governmental authority that has recognized and certified an exclusive collective bargaining representative may negotiate with the representative an alternative method of forming a hearing board.
A correctional officer may elect the alternative method of forming a hearing board if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the correctional officer works in a correctional facility described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph; and
the correctional officer is included in the collective bargaining unit.

subparagraph.text: The internal investigation unit shall notify the correctional officer in writing before a hearing board is formed that the correctional officer may elect an alternative method of forming a hearing board if one has been negotiated under this paragraph.
If the correctional officer elects the alternative method, that method shall be used to form the hearing board.
